w8-DtfvliccMIiTfBVEo6Q.text: I would give it six stars if I could. This place surpasses any ramen shop I visited in Boston or NewYork (yes, more impressive than Totto or Sapora etc.) I ordered the Tan Tan Ramen, whose soup base is AMAZING - with a touch of spiciness but not too heavy; make sure to choose to have noodle cooked the hardest way. My fiancé had another ramen (sry forgot the name lol) which was equally fantastic, and his soup base tastes totally different from mine - unlike a lot of other ramen places where dishes share similar base. Service is decent. We arrived ~9pm Sunday night and there was no queue.

T8Mx1udbCBtBZx2RRRtDsQ.text: I like this Ramen place lot. Great service and great food. the Bun is so-so, I will only recommend the Ramen here. I will going back if I have a chance.

mNLU-xICM-cRNNqdlt_HKw.text: I found Shoryu Ramen to be much better than bone daddies!  However, I never found bone daddies to be traditional style ramen in the first place...We arrived Sunday afternoon and we were seated immediately.  I got their classic Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and the wife got the Piri Piri Tonkotsu which is their spiciest ramen.  Both looked great and tasted even better!They even give you the option for 4 different sizes noodles, however, we stuck with the classic thin hosomen noodles (original) ...not sure if they were homemade but they tasted very good.Am looking forward to going back to try some of their more creative ramen like the 'Dracula Tonkotsu'?!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu with extra chilli
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Piri Piri Tonkotsu

Cd4zwrqfLVSqiN7nDkQJ2g.text: This place definitely hit the spot on a rainy and cold day in London! My friend and I were lucky to make it to the shop before the kitchen closes (they close 30 min before their posted closing time). We didn't have that much time left to order but we were definitely satisfied with what we got!We both ordered the Piri Piri Shoryu Ramen, it's the spicy version of the Shoryu Ramen. We both loved our ramen! The noodles tasted very fresh and the broth was very flavorful and had the right amount of spice! I wouldn't recommend getting the Piri Piri if you are just looking for a little bit of heat. The green tea and raspberry mochi were the perfect treat to end our dinner.I forgot to mention that service was really friendly too. I've had good ramen back in the a States before and I think this place is very good. The only downside about it is that everything is so expensive in London. Back in the States, you can get a lot of extra toppings and customize your own ramen for much cheaper at very well known ramen shops. However, it is what it is and I definitely enjoyed Shoryu Ramen! I would definitely recommend this place to anyone! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Piri Piri Shoryu Ramen (spicy)

WZGCDUk75SUA8z0Jtxfh_g.text: My next favorite place for ramen in London, 2nd to kanada-ya. The ramen is great, and the side dishes are also delicious. Only downside is that the ramen sometimes feels abit greasy imo. Btw, the curry ramen is really good actually but it's not a popular choice so I'm recommending it here.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Curry Ramen

b3p1cjGs1D7JWtxXeVbBcw.text: Had the kotteri tonkotsu ramen and a beer. Noodles were decent, roasted pork a bit small, boiled egg was good. Soup tasted like it had noodle flour in it and also the kitchen had dumped a massive pile of pickled ginger on top which made the soup taste oddly fishy. The draft beer was Kirin, decent but not spectacular- on the menu it said that it would be served very cold but it was several degrees above that. Price for a bowl of ramen 12 quid, with today's exchange rate making the ramen at least 3 times what one would pay for the same food in Japan. Service was friendly if a bit disorganized on a crowded Saturday afternoon, but the buy 1 ramen get the second half-off coupon that I used made up for any slowness and probably saved Shoryu from a trip to 2-starland, for now three is the number of the stars thou shalt count, and the number of the counting shall be three.

yzt3fSEsaLXweUkUdxuswQ.text: Was not happy with the service.  The lady did not comprehend what I was asking. I ordered the regular ramen w the fried shallots and I had asked her if it was simply the basic ramen w the Pork and egg plus the added ingredient of fried shallots. Took me about Three minutes to ask what I needed to ask until I gave up and went with it. And she still didn't understand. Service was terrible overall The ramen was ok. A bit oily. I prefer kanada-ya ramen over shoryu

mVoDv1vJ4ZjYYE3eKdiWcA.text: Now I see what all the hype is surrounding Ramen.  With a sore throat and the desire for some fresh vegetables, we happily chose to eat here for some ramen. I ordered the vegetarian bowl with extra mushrooms and my friend ordered the traditional pork Ramen bowl. Although it took some getting use to using the spoon and chopsticks, we really enjoyed our fresh soup and I'm wishing there was a great ramen place in Tampa bay.

mugNDhXhtoMQEo0o0Y-Rrg.text: Great place last minute when a more popular ramen place had a line out the door.Service was a bit slow but they were just finishing up their night so it is to be expected when closing up other areas of the shop. Will def return.

wwUXaE0z9viI9W591J4dew.text: My wife and I loved this place.  There was a short wait to get a table as the place was packed but certainly worth the wait.  The broth was savory, the noodles were cooked perfectly, and the portion was just the right size.  I don't really associate London with ramen but my wife and I will certainly be back!

epK78Jaz6DFkGtkEcBGUDg.text: Delicious! I went to London for a weekend and I absolutely wanted to try Shoryu after all the excellent reviews I read. I waited for 30 min on a cold night but it was definitely worth the wait. I ordered a Karaka Tantan Tonkotsu ramen and loved it ! The noodles were perfectly cooked and broth was yummy & spicy.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

eOQsBf78BlsbjcqFbgfbUw.text: Visiting London and was trying to find a delicious Ramen place. Checked out Yelp and this was the top rated one nearby our hotel. I see how it was top rated. The service was very attentive and quick. The Ramen man it was delish the broth was super tasty. I ordered the spicy mince pork one while my bf ordered the most popular ramen dish. I prefered my broth for it was less richer. Overall if ever back in London would definitely come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Green Tea Mochi
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Kotteri hakata tonkatsu ramen

NOpADoPLvDhGZYvhUzA87Q.text: Quite disappointed with the pork belly bun, the pork was great but while the bun looked well made, it seemed to have been "restored" in the microwave. Even with a full set of teeth there was no tearing through that bun.    But alas, then the ramen arrived, I had the Karaha Tantan Tonkosu Ramen.  I was totally blown away. I was just in Tokyo in January and this bowl rivaled my favorites there. Perfect texture and wonderful warming heat! I could not get this dish out of my mind and returned to their other Soho location two days later! Even with the bulletproof bun, I am still giving 5 stars!

8hNB9VNdGNlWbOxk3qyXYw.text: Yum yum yum!Was looking for authentic Japanese ramen and definitely found it here! Even my parents approved/they loved it!Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu: Perfect ramen if you're looking for a savory hearty ramen. Hirata Buns: ****OH MY GOODNESS. Must try. delicious.Chicken Kara Age: Can never go wrong with fried chicken :)It gets pretty busy so I'll definitely be back on a slow day/night.

d_IXdQvjNF5fdqETMPaMyw.text: I can't believe it has taken me so long to write this review.THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!I remember the first time I discovered this place: I was on bus 23 towards Picadilly Circus when I saw the huge line of Japanese outside this little place. Intrigued, I went back the next day, stood in line in the cold for half an hour having no idea what was expecting me. Basically, I didn't know what ramen was until I stepped foot here.Obviously, I've seen the light and consider myself a convert. My new religion is ramen. Ramen is a bowl of soup, mostly on pork stock, with noodles, half an egg, some veggies - but the description doesn't do it justice, as ramen is a state of mind. The absolutely sensational feeling of well being when you sip on the soup, chew on the noodles. Then the wonderful feeling hours after you've had your ramen.. Ahh.. I usually go for the Tokyo Ramen, but last time Ulrik tried the cold ramen and it was soooo good! A new favourite for sure.Go, wait in line, eat, be happy!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Cold ramen - go for it!

j7cg7XxX_-f1M3fCA8YJPA.text: It's very hard for me to go and change a venue for something new especially when it comes to Ramen. Although this was a good choice. Food was very tasty. Service was cool too. I will definitely come back when I am back in London. Thanks

k2rNhcs1HJC4oX43hk5pdw.text: Really good ramen! Okra appetizer looks deceptively simple but really yummy.  The broth is less pork-y, if you know what I mean.  This really hits the spot when you're looking for ramen and thankfully now there are a few locations so less chance that you'll have to queue.I would have given five stars but it's a little while since I've been so I'm going to have to visit again and update my review.  A good excuse to have ramen at Shoryu again!

aqMwhPDtnG5yBDm0RkUtyg.text: The shoryu ban with pork and chicken is very delicious. The Piri Piri Tonkotsu is kind of spicy but it tastes good.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Piri Piri Tonkotsu

KhtXcZraCagpxr3j_CpIJg.text: Not that good as I had too much good experience in HK. The food did not meet my expectation. The pork belly bun is too fatty for me and the steamed bun is not that soft, the sauce is not strong. The dumpling is nothing special. Will not go again But the staff is very helpful there

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. The pork bun is too fatty really!
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Dumpling, not recommend

gkqTVqNeJmj48KCEgQcxGg.text: Shoryu think you can cook Ramen! Honestly this restaurant was AMAZING. Great service that was friendly and quick and the best food I've had in awhile. I highly recommend the pork belly bun, edamame beans, and ramen! I would go again!

2AtWoY6AIZQsMnn074iLVg.text: Typical Tonkotsu place.  Nothing special, frankly, it's really over-hyped.  Ramen could have been out of preserved or dried packages, Kimchi was not especially tasty (probably made more palatable for unsophisticated western's taste) and the shrimps on the seafood's Tonkotsu seemed straight out of the refrigerator, they were cold inside the warm soup which was an unpleasant contrast.I finished ordering a Macha ice cream which didn't certainly taste artisanal.If you want to get real Japanese ramen in Europe I'll suggest trying in Düsseldorf.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Seafood Kimchi Tonkotsu

W9C6Hg1LAyjE1lU4UTOiEw.text: Pretty disappointed by this place. It looks very sexy with decor etc, but service was really poor - and I was there for dinner at 5.30pm before a show.  I finally got a menu and realised there wasn't much veggie choice (which I guess is to be expected, so that's not a biggie) but I opted for a pancake which sounded intriguing. Well, we waited 40 mins for food, and only after enquiring were brought an undercooked and frankly bizarrely chewy dish, minus the advertised salad. I would normally have sent something like this back, but by this point we were in a rush and there seemed to be no point, so I just graciously ate, then tried and failed to pay using Apple Pay. I think this is just not for me, and won't return,,,

xfSIaqu7wiLdXe9_-pKkqw.text: This place is nice and comfortable inside. We only waited about 15 minutes to be seated.I ordered the pork belly bun and the spicy tonkatsu ramen. The pork belly bun had a great flavor profile that was different from most that I have had. It had a sweet, smoky, and light spice to it.My ramen was quite good except for the pickled ginger. I was not a fan. I ordered my ramen standard, but will opt for the firmer option for chewy purposes.If you are in the mood for ramen then you can't go wrong here.

EvR1nKYwodT50wtkejHsPQ.text: This was my first authentic ramen experience. Beside top ramen and the local noodle bar, I had a very limited taste palette. As soon as you walk in you get this awesome sense of surrounding. The space is beautifully decorated. Very chic. We sat by the front to get a view of the street and the life outside. Our started was some pot stickers. They came out still sizzling. Very crispy and full. Great way to start. For my main I got the Origin Tonkostu. And wow. Ike nothing I ever tasted. And it was huge! There was no way I could finish it.....but I tried! By the time we left, our bellies were full and swishing. Extremely satisfied with our meals. If you like unique and authentic ramen, this is your place.

sRKnhd5YePU3VijI2xp0Rw.text: We were around Regent/Piccadilly Circus after watching a musical in this area so we stopped by this place to eat Ramen. Their selection of dishes on their menu is wide, so you will find something you like. If you are not familiar with Japanese food, they also have a glossary on their menu in case you have trouble with finding out what you want and need a closer explanation. We ordered a Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu, their signature dish with extra meat, and also some fried gyoza. We finished our ramen and also our beer, and waited long for the gyoza. So we had to ask, and it seems they had forgotten about this order. They apologized and made the food right away when we pointed that out, so it was not the end of the world. But normally the gyoza should have come before the ramen as gyoza is considered more as an appertizer. So in short this a good place to eat Ramen with good service, but it is not the best Ramen place around this area as they have a lot of competition here.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

kP4hyCAtoGqtAenvFyyNGA.text: Just what I needed when touring the Trafalgar Square area. I enjoyed their signature ramen (pork, egg, mushrooms over noodles) and others had the sashimi which was fresh and filling. Excellent service too. Would definitely recommend.

nOR-0Mzo5pVe83YiNeFSsQ.text: GLUTEN FREE RAMEN!!! And also gluten free sides including chicken karaage (Japanese fried chicken) and steamed buns! I didn't go full GF as I got the Shoryu ganso tonkotsu but with rice noodles instead of egg noodles. For full GF you have the choice of two soy milk and white miso ramen. My ramen was so deeeelicious and the egg was just perfect. Really good pork too. All in all amazing. My husband had the Dracula ramen...woah, he stunk so bad afterwards and we were going to the theatre, hahaha! And yep, it was even worse the morning after. Prepare yourself for the most garlicy dish ever. It was delicious though. We also had the traditional Japanese chicken wings on ice for starter, just because it sounded cool. The wings were nice though I'm not sure why they are served on ice...My husband also got the winter sake flight, 3 types of sake (35ml each I think) for £6.50 with an explanation of what each one was. A great idea to educate people about sake!There were so many other interesting things here, the sides, the drinks. What a great meal! Will definitely be coming back...is tomorrow too soon?!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Signature ramen with rice noodles instead of egg noodles.

fkCs7_PqLEVc7GKLJ-NFcg.text: We got there by sunday lunchtime on a cold day and there was already a couple of people queueing. it didn't take too long though (luckily it wasn't raining) and we were shown to our table. the place is rather small and these were two tables joined together, with table 2 already occupied. i don't know why they couldn't have separated the tables before we took our seats but that's fine, we did it ourselves.I had a steamed pork bun as a started and the price was quite steep for what is essentially a mini sandwich. The meat was somewhat flavoursome, but a bit dry and sat awkwardly inside the bun, trying to escape as I bit into it. I don't know, presentation wasn't great and I felt there was little value for money. I had the traditional ramen with two lovely half eggs and bits of pork that were ok, but not mind blowingly good as the ones I had in Tokyo. The broth was substantial and nicely flavoured, but I must be honest and said I've had better here in London. The price is honest for what you get, though, and I've heard you can get a second portion of noodles free if you still have lots of broth left. For drinks I've ordered a frozen kirin but it came mildy warm and without the foam cap it was supposed to have. I was disappointed to say the least.Overall the food ain't bad, it's just not awesome enough to make me queue or even go for another visit. And I believe you could have better elsewhere.

w9z5UZii8HkhyAU7uJEndA.text: Was starving and indecisive so when I turned the corner and saw a large line of people waiting outside of Shoryu, I knew it must be 1.) a new favorite yelp spot or 2.) super good...either way that made up my mind and I joined the line. I ordered their classic Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and it was just delicious. Aghh buttery and rich and flavorful....aghh im salivating thinking of it all over again. It was about 11 GBP (around $16 USD) for a bowl which is a little more expensive then the $12 bowls I am used to in DC (I guess both are kind of expensive for a bowl of soup when you think about it), then again this is London and everything is expensive here. ANYWAY back to the food. It was delicious and I would definitely give it my recommendation!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu......DELICIOUS!!!!

wd8dAE4kQeDKZF-1mf_FZA.text: I don't live in London. I was only visiting for a week. Stumbled upon this little gem. Loved it so much that I haaaad to dine here twice. No shame. Had the pleasure of trying their Tantan, Spicy Miso, Piri piri and Curry. Piri piri was my favorite, but it's definitely spicy. Prepare yourselves! The jalapenos give it an extra kick! Tan Tan would be my second fave. The boiled egg is perfectly made every time too! Deco is trendy and modern. Service is hospitable and quick. Lucky for us, when we went both times, there wasn't really a wait. Shoryu is right next to Piccadilly, so perfect for a stroll before or after you wine and dine!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

3OI8Nk5nfFhbT_MgHx4tyw.text: Perfect, no-nonsense ramen. The soup is not insanely thick like some other competitors'. I like it. Also, their octopus appetizer is fantastic.

Nm1W4oCvBPcWjV1LLQmEDA.text: A nice broth, good taste to the pork, fun staff who rings a gong and meets you with a happy greeting upon entering, and a delicious matcha latte.  I honestly prefer Kanada-Ya, but I may go back here to give it another try (and this time, I will specify my noodle preference because they were much too soft for my taste).

RQ00SYjbam4ds_sO5cHbng.text: Small ramen shop in Piccadilly. We were lucky to have a short wait since they don't take reservations.Attentive and polite staff await you in this busy restaurant. I had the kotteri ramen, which was well prepared, flavourful and rich. I decided to go with the extra hard noodles and they were a good choice! The shoyu pork bun did underwhelm a bit; the strength of the sauce and mayo (?) didn't allow you to enjoy the pork. Not worth it in my opinion, but the ramen is worth going back for!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Kotteri ramen with pork shoyu buns.
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Warm green tea.

5Ft-Cs2xRFlQ0tM2CA4GFA.text: The Shiitake & Konbu Gluten Free Soy Broth, Tofu, Kikurage, Seasoned Beansprouts, Sweet Corn, Spring Onion, Sesame, Spinach And Menma Bamboo was some of the best ramen I have ever had. Bursting with so much flavor. It was perfection. I am vegetarian and it is hard and quite rare to encounter ramen that is this yummy. I highly recommend this ramen spot for anyone looking for some quality food with a nice fun atmosphere. For dessert I had the green tea cheesecake and the texture and flavor was on point. If I had more room in my stomach, I would have also got the yuzu cheesecake. That will have to be for my next visit to London. Amazing food with quality, friendly inviting staff, fun atmosphere

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Green tea cheesecake perfection
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Yummy beer
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. This one is for the vegetarians out there

IooQrznvbf7SFaCVmAwo5w.text: I just tried Ippudo in NYC few days ago where Hirata Buns and Ramen are PERFECT. So basically when you come to Shoryu Ramen in London, the deception is normal.The Waguy Beef Hirata is BAD, very fatty, the bun doesn't hold and it is drenched in mayonnaise !! (£7.5)The fried chichen Ramen, is a large portion with several big pieces of Fried chicken (bland) that lost their crispness because of the broth.The broth is flavourful but nothing compared to Ippudo.The 1 star is for the location.The minus 4 stars are basically more for the lack of service i got from the staff.  They are not motivated and not welcoming. I really was about to leave cause i felt i disturbed them. They were several empty seats/table but they offered the one very mext to the main door (bear in mind it is freezing outside and the clients are entering and flgoing out from this door)When i insisted to get the seat inside that i knew was free they told me no. I was abot to give up but eventually they gave me that seat after mumbling about me.That is how my experience started at shoryu and believe me l, i was still expecting the food to be good despite the attitude of some staff.It is very expensive for nothing and no need to say that i won't recommend it.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Hirata Mayonnaise!!

zVtl3uh7xD2aNV8VOC7dDQ.text: London's best ramen restaurant. I like their food. But I don't understand why they make people queue even if they have enough tables. That's unfair. That's why I can't give them 5stars.

TgAMB8Xj61GLjTJnYVVW2w.text: I bloody love Shoryu! I haven't eaten a lot of ramen but from what I know this is really good stuff! The portions are huge and for the price totally worth it! I had the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu and it was amazing! Delicious thick broth, succulent pork and perfect soft boiled eggs.Sure this ramen thing is a bit of a London fad at the moment but who cares?! It tastes great and it fills the hole!Oh, and they also do FROZEN BEER!!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Frozen Kirin! As the missus said "looks like a snowman's poo"

0jtJZvixIgNsizbeFClUHQ.text: Believe the hype. It's REAL. Just a few steps from touristy Piccadilly Circus, this gem is legit. Complex flavor, amazing service, solid recommendations. Do yourself a favor and make it here. It'll be worth every slurp of your soup.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Curry ramen (to DIE for) with gluten free noodles (now I can die HAPPY)

t3KfUqAbmyjezYvQshGEcw.text: Great broth, noodles, and overall excellent variation on this Japanese dish. Loved the piri piri and fresh jalapeños for heat. Definitely would come again.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Piri piri ramen

jObp7TfzgDF-tCNEOodP0Q.text: I was walking and on my way to a different restaurant when I passed by this place. The place had this warm and inviting vibe to it. Or maybe it was the rain that made me want to just grab a bowl of ramen.  So I decided to forgo the steak I was about to go enjoy and walked into this place. The staff was friendly and attentive and seated me right away.  Took a look at the menu and decided on the Kimchi seafood ramen along with the pork and prawn tempura buns along with a sake flight.Long story short everything was amazing. The buns were perfect and amazing. I wanted more but I had a whole bowl of ramen I needed to eat. So I start the ramen and the broth is just die to for. Perfect amount of heat along with perfectly cooked seafood. The noodles were not overcooked and had the right amount of chewiness. So good that I am promising myself that I will go back on every trip I make to London.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Sake flight.
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. All the food I am about to devour!

_Jslj8uuxxKFyGpqKop3DA.text: The Takana was pretty amazing! Our Japanese entourage concurred the noodles were legit and the gyoza were pretty amazing as well. It's a small little shop in one of the busiest spots of London, which means you might hit a queue. I was pretty lucky at noon on a weekend and we only waited about 10 min but by the time we left, the wait looked considerably longer. There seems to be a lot of ramen popping up around town, if you're on the hunt to compare, put Shoryu on your shortlist.

mbiccyQ1zuH8KkVq0jvqlg.text: Came up to London to fulfill some Japanese Ramen cravings with my friends. Totally worth the 1.5-2 hours for our trip. I asked what the most popular dish was and the waitress told me the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu. I absolutely LOVED it! At first I was confused on why I didn't have any Chashyu, and then I realized that I had gotten "pan fried minced pork" this was so much more delicious than the chashyu (pork slices). The meat was very juicy, a little bit too salty, but I liked it that way. There was a good portion of noodles and the bowl was quite large. I also liked the spicyness of the ramen dish!If I lived in London, I would eat here as often as I could! I think the price is very reasonable and there are a bunch of side dishes that you can get as well. The place was quite upscale looking and super clean!

HnoJLzl1I4AF2ymv_5Zm9Q.text: Stopped in with my mom after reading other reviews.  We were seated quickly and were told about the menu and their specialties. We weren't planning on getting any buns, but it happened to be 2-for-1 bun night. We ordered two bowls of ramen and two pork belly buns. The ramen came out hot and flavorful, very large portions. The buns were a good size and very good. If we ever visit London again, I would definitely come back and I would order more buns and share a bowl of ramen.

1Mr6iYtmTALVc0e1tUg-5Q.text: DinnerWent there with my cousin and her boy friend. In total it costed £40 for three of us. Therefore i shouldn't be so judge mental? However, ramen in Japan is a serious topic, can be the theme for life. I think it could earn four stars as the quality of food was great overall, but the bean sprout tasted old, kinda sourly almost people from FSA will question about its freshness. Shame.Maybe it's one off.Thus highly recommended for a casual dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

GY4tpC51J9LH28yVQvffvA.text: I am a ramen-freak. It's what I crave when I am happy, sad, stressed, or celebrating. Shoryu satisfies all my cravings and it amazing!Coming from New York, I have a pretty high standard for ramen (at least I would like to think so), so once I moved here, I had to find here I could feast on delicious pork belly and noodles. After reading a bunch of reviews I tried a few places out, and so far Shoryu is my favorite. I've been back a few times since finding it too. Each time I come hungry because the bowls are massive! And of course I have to save room for the fantastic hirata pork buns!The place is relatively small and cramped, but that's London for small restaurants. It is still very nice and the atmosphere is great. Servers greet you when you come in and the servers are always nice and efficient. If you need a dose of ramen in your life check this place out. I have gone with native Chinese and Japanese friends and they give their stamp of approval too! The broth is always salty and deliciously umami-like, the meet is tender, and the noodles don't lose their sogginess after ten minutes in the bowl, which is nice. Go, feast, enjoy, return.

iVq-T8ETenVGmw91qyrWvg.text: Most amazing ramen! We eat ramen in New York often and this is even better. We went multiple times on our short trip. LOVE!

fhOmGEMzpeCh_4UgpJJClQ.text: I am a devoted Ramen fan who spent years in Japan actively seeking the perfect bowl of noodles.  I even took it so far as collecting business cards from all the shops and making a binder with notes on each.  Of course, you have to judge Ramen outside Japan with a slightly relaxed standard, because it's hard to replicate the full environment.That said, Shoryu is a solid bowl of noodles.  Tonkotsu is my favorite variety of Ramen, and these guys get it right.  The soup is thick and fragrant and the noodles have the right amount of chewiness.  I only go to London a few times per year, but Shoryu is definitely on my must-go list from now on.

MG5vj-Xvud-qTZmOLBds4A.text: This is one of those places in London that satisfies my ramen craving. Love love loooove.When I first entered the restaurant, gongs were sounded based by the number of people you have in your party. *so honoured* Then we were sat, and a complimentary small saucer filled with cold yet crunchy cabbage(?) is served. For my first time here I ordered the Dracula ramen. It is one of the newer food options and it's delicious! Definitely gives you garlic breath after to ward off the vampires later on, but who cares? Great food requires great sacrifices. Second time was Yuzu ramen for me. Might feel weird at first glance because yuzu is a citrus fruit, but when mixed with the salty tonkotsu base, it is actually something quite sensational. Not one of my favourites, but my impression of Shoryu is still higher than ever. Love the ambience here as well - although everyone is sat pretty close, it's not too noisy and the lighting and overall decoration and furniture makes it a good mix of classy and cosy. The service here is amazing - I can tell that they try to emulate the Japanese service here, and that makes it so welcoming to me. Price-wise is reasonable in comparison to other ramen restaurants in London. Shoryu definitely wins in the value-for-money department. Will come back again and again and again. I'll never be bored of ramen.

Kseya9sOMBj_Y7045Aq8aQ.text: This is a fantastic, traditional ramen place with reasonable pieces and good drinks. I've been to Japan 40 times and j would come back here in a heartbeat.

U5eqf1b_Rm7eaa2kWIgQbw.text: Well isn't this place an absolute delight! Ramen is pretty much tailor made for miserable London winters and as the days get progressively greyer and grimmer, I'll be making a beeline for Shoryu. You should too. The noodles are fresh and bountiful (perhaps a little too bountiful but there are worse problems to have, hey), the broth rich and flavoursome and the meat and veggies seasoned to perfection. The gyoza is also pretty great, but there's no way you'll have space for it after the ramen. Honestly, if I didn't you won't. On top of this, the setup is really nice and cosy and does away with the canteen style feel that often comes with ramen spots. I'll be back.

mg0sZwGGOK3BQRbr1l1fAg.text: Love my asian soups and especially Ramen.  Wow did this place impress and surpass my favorite NYC ramen places.   Aside from the impeccably authentic ramen with velvet noodles and broth, the side orders were also exceptional (pork belly buns were unbelievably fluffy, the gyoza was rediculously crisp, shrimp tempura was light and crispy and my kids devoured the tempura Brussels sprouts).   This place is the real deal and a must stop for Ramen lovers.

Qm-ztoYCPmoI15xgNoCqXQ.text: Ordered two ramen n a black sesame tofu. I'm in love with the tofu but not a ramen fan sorry. The dining place is a bit small. We feel lucky to have a friendly n fast service thank you

hVOY3JQXZzwOlXc6zUnHlQ.text: Im still looking for any sort of flavor in the vegetarian ramen (am i asking for the moon?!)

EFzd6AwSof0AjrMuncfk8A.text: Amazing Ramen place! A bit crowded but service was reasonable. We had two different kinds of ramen and buns. Buns were a great surprise. The ramen was served at perfect temperature and was really tasty. The wife had never had ramen and doesn't eat much soup but was really excited afterwards and ready to go back on our next trip!

e8XqXulQIzshBji2y6qMsw.text: I'm really disappointed at the quality of this restaurant. I ordered a Karaage and Shoryu Ramen .Karaage was good but the Ramen did not have much of a taste.  the noodle was not japanese one it maybe Chainese noodle ??.......it was too soft noodle.I will try ohter Ramen shop .........

aoAPO9dZjZHydP6sryEPoA.text: This is a chain in the city but the ramen is great. We were glad we got their early as by 6:30 there was a line outside. Great place for a casual and quick meal. So good we are here twice on our trip!

qilHQzf7CTWAXPVuADrIuw.text: Excellent ramen.  Good service.  Kirin Ichiban on tap.  A little pricey and a little cramped.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Nice bar.  Lots of sake.

ARUoTvTj-Uocn3_MCn38aQ.text: The broth was rich and tasty! The noodles were cooked perfectly - not too soft, not too hard! We only waited for about 20 mins or so on a Saturday night so that wasn't too bad. Service was alright and we can't wait to go back again~!

txEGK4_y9cQ3YKpGIMTUMw.text: I would have given it 4 stars. The service was very polite and nice but inattentive. I waited forever to place an order, and waited forever to get attention to get the dessert menu, and almost knocked the waitress serving the next table over, actually she almost knocked me over, as I was trying to leave.  Food was pretty good. Ramen soup (tonkutso) was excellent, and yummily garnished. I had the matcha ramen and was good. succulent texture. Hirata bun was oversized, fluffy and pillowy, and chewy, but there was something indecently inelegant about it. Pork belly was ok - doesn't quite melt in your mouth and of course you couldnt go wrong with the mayo. Mmmm. I also tried the gluten free hirata bun and they microwaved it!! So the ends ended up being very hard. But where I could chew it was actually tasty and the texture quite good - not as soft and pillowy but decent and tasty! If you are going for the gf hirata buns (which only comes in chicken), ask them not to microwave but to steam it.  The matcha tea was absolutely disappointing. It said stoneground in restaurant but it was hardly tasty - i felt like i was drinking plain water.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu signature ramen. With matcha noodles. Very filled. Very tasty. Noodles not bad at all. Succulent.
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Hirata buns with pork belly. Soft like a pillow. Tasty. Bigger serving than the gf one.
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Gluten free hirata buns with chicken age. With pickle and lettuce.  bun tasty, no soppy gf texture, chewy but hard

EOINZLNG3bIahA-UuqbMFw.text: I was in London on holiday craving some ramen and found this spot listed on a lot of dining lists for top ramen spot in London. I decided to check it out and ordered some standard miso ramen and an order of pork buns. The pork buns came out first and it was not yummy at all! Seems like the pork belly was old and the buns were not soft at all - instead of being nicely steamed it tasted and looked like frozen microwaved pork buns. The ramen was underwhelming as well. The eggs were not cooked how I liked (yokey yellow and brown soy sauce soaked). The noodles were ok, I've had much better. The noodles tasted like they were sitting out in room temperature for too long. The broth was very watered down. I was so upset after reading good reviews about this place and left 80% of my order untouched.

nRY-Cg5ne3Xg534R2oVvCQ.text: My first visited the one near canary street and the best Ramen I ever had, then went to the one in Soho couple week later..not really feel the same at all, may be different Ramen I ordered.

33jvL-Bo5APcnY43-aRWcg.text: I have become a fairly regular customer at the Denman Street Shoryu and this was my first trip to the 'other' Shoryu Ramen. I can happily say that the food is just as good here. The ambience is the same as well. I had a cold ramen - the chef's special something, it was - and it came with the Ramen on a straw mat with ice below it. Very visually appealing and definitely worth the 12 pounds-ish that I paid for it. The seating is a bit close together and it can be uncomfortable if you are here to have some intimate conversation. Of course, its not a problem if you can talk in a few different languages (Hindi, Malayalam, English) according to the people sitting around you - making sure that your privacy is maintained. Haha.

ZQMNSKaGbNnPZJGoz4k60Q.text: A short walk from Piccadilly Circus, you'll find a cozy little ramen shop that serves up hot noodles, broth and tea. As a first timer, I took the safe route and picked the popular Karaka Miso Buta Tonkatsu Ramen (9.90), and although there was a tiny mix up with our orders, it got to us eventually, and still in quick fashion. I must say I was quite pleased with my selection... the broth was tasty, not too heavy, and the portion size was just right. Another treat was the Genmai Tea, I couldn't stop drinking it, it was so good! Oh yeah, get the gyoza. There's nothing ever really special about gyoza, but it's always good. Service was quick and attentive and they even gave us coupons for next time. Need something hot to warm up on these cold winter days? Ramen might just hit the spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Dragon Ramen
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Ramen time!
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Spicy Miso

r-NsWlsMUTU6dvncV1jxmg.text: The vegan white natural soup was amazing. I've tried many vegetarian ramens and this was by far the best tasting broth I have ever had. It's a pity I discovered it on my second to last day in London.

ZeyOXFlbEM3kJzkWlKRPSQ.text: Having tried the other recent Ramen places that have popped up in London, I thought I'd give this place the chance.... Now I know it's all personal preference but this place wasn't for me. To be fair I went for the signature  tonkatsu (as I have in all the others) all the ingredients were there and the noodles were good, however the soup just was a little salty and bland. We accompanied the Ramen with steamed pork buns that were very good though!! The layout of the restaurant is a little bit awkward also, the entrance door inconveniences at least two tables and if you need to use the only toilet then you will again have to disturb people.Overall, fairly good and slightly cheaper than the rest but defiantly trailing  the others in my opinion.

MxpsVlrskB6pRA7fQJb-fw.text: Great service, amazing food...get the dumplings (guitar) and the shoryu buns and have fun beyond that...such a cool place

Qq-Xr_hVsEXl7WpM6K3Ecw.text: So much ramen, so little time. And you need time if you want to go to Shoryu as the line is quite often 10-15 people long on any given evening. We went on the soft-opening week which meant the line was even longer although props to the staff for shoving us in as fast as possible and having no qualms about asking random people to sit together.  However, I didn't quite understand why they split the group up when the table the first pair was given was more than enough for all of us. We swapped the randoms for our friends and everyone was happy (except for the waitress who looked like she was about to punch a hole in the wall).The Ramen itself was good (I chose the Shoryu Special) with a rich creamy white broth that was an excellent argument on its own for taking the slow boil method for making tonkotsu stock. The pork itself wasn't that flavourful and I remember being a little disappointed in the low amount of veggies. Those that were there were excellent and so was the egg. The bowl is a massive serving and I happily slurped my way into fatty pork nirvana.It's a bit cramped inside with the planners seemingly hell bent on working out how to maximise the number of people per square meter. Be prepared to get close to some strangers and even cosier with your friends. Then again, we all survive the tube in rush hour so by comparison this is downright luxurious! In the London Ramen rankings, the overall food is good but not enough to dethrone Bone Daddies as the London Ramen King!

HcFuCYjVLEL1es60HqYmqQ.text: And so continues my ramen quest!  I just moved here, and I'm on a mission to find my favorite ramen restaurant in London.  So far nothing makes me want to strip naked and jump inside the hot vat of soupy goodness, ecstatically yelling YES as I beat two slices of pickled turnips together in excitement.Shoryu was half full by the time I got there at 7 pm, but packed by the time I left at 8.  I was seated quickly, and ordered the £9.9 Takana Tonkotsu with a £3 side of menma and £1.5 of egg, as well as the £6 shishito peppers.  Nice but quite expensive additions.  5 minutes later (I do appreciate the fast service here, way faster than Bone Daddy's), I had a hot steaming bowl of ramen.  They're not stingy with the portion either.The noodles were al dente and the broth was certainly flavorful, but missing the fattiness that I prefer.  In fact, it was a bit watery. I preferred the pork at BD as it was softer and fattier.  Update: I came here again, and ordered the Wasabi Tonkotsu and Karaka Miso Buta Tonkotsu.  Loved the Buta Tonkotsu, there were tons of ground pork in it and the noodles were perfect!  Couldn't really taste much of the wasabi in the other tonkotsu, definitely preferred the Buta.

vPSrQI7dV3xMquMQQjIKmA.text: IMO, far and away the best ramen in London (after Shoryu, of the places I've been I'd rank them Tonkotsu, Ittenbari, Bone Daddies, Yugo, Mitsukoshi). Good noodles, egg is of the perfect doneness, and the tonkotsu broth is fantastic, very balanced.My personal favorite (and supposedly the favorite of the staff) is the Karaka Tantan Tonkotsu, spicier and with garlic.I'm from the San Francisco Bay Area and I'd say Shoryu is similar in quality to Ramen Dojo there, and also similar in that they both have spicy ramen. Personally, I don't think anywhere else in London comes close.

lvA2s0A8hEnwFJVeQz-PLg.text: solid ramen place. Not the best ramen i have had but not the worst. the service is pretty good. solid place if you are in central and want ramen.

EceJ-sWaQwydqIO2IWG4oA.text: The key to a great ramen is the broth. The broth here is great, therefore the ramen is great.I had the char siu ramen - the original ramen plus extra pork, and my wife had the Dracula ramen, which had caramelised garlic. I got to try her broth at the end: it was garlicky indeed, but still very nice. Noodles were cooked just right and the pork slices were nice. As you would expect, mine had a lot of pork slices which were a treat. An unusual element was the pickled ginger. It's a surprise when you eat it, but makes for a good occasional contrast to the rest of the ramen.We got our usual sides of karaage chicken and gyoza. The gyoza came with a nice ginger dipping sauce. The karaage chicken was made from chicken breast, which was ok but I have noticed that the thigh meat has more flavour and is juicier.We got an Asahi each too. They came with a half pint glass of the sort you would find in an English pub, which I liked.Our total bill came to £48 with service.  This is about average or just under for the ramen places that we have visited in London. I would come back here, but probably just for the ramen.The place is an easy walk, just down the hill, from Picadilly tube station.  There was a small queue outside when we got there at around 6:30pm and this grew during the evening.  This is something to bear in mind - however, ramen appears to be one of the trendy things at the moment, so most good ramen places would be like this.

OBboe_t5DK_n6KM1jE9cZw.text: A die hard fan of ramen, I can safely say that ShorYu's ramen will not disappoint. Eggs could have been done better, but the broth was delicious!

bkJ6VdHeIULOhLl-hVw2Vw.text: If you're wondering about that wasabi tonkotsu, I too was curious before finally coming here on Sunday.. I had checked out their ramen selection in advance to see what they had to offer compared to the other ramen joints..and wasabi ramen is definitely a new one for me. So I will start with the con. They have a scoop of pasty wasabi shavings when your bowl is brought out untouched, along with the atypical bean sprouts, earwigs, pork, and two sheets of seaweed (sorry, gotta pay extra for an egg!). The pasty wasabi shaving was not very potent, especially when I mixed it in with my broth. The beauty of wasabi is that spicy zing shooting up one's nose with every bite, and I had imagined every bite of this ramen would do me the same justice; on the contrary, it was very subtle. I have seen broth prepared with wasabi oil to give it a strong kick but this broth is not wasabi flavored and the only thing giving it the wasabi love was the scoop of wasabi bits on top of the noodles. Don't get me wrong, the broth was excellent, very milky and not overtly salty.. but just wasn't what I was expecting when ordering wasabi tonkotsu. While there's no doubt you can make out the faint taste of wasabi, the taste was too repressed for me. Don't lie to yourself and say you've ever gone for wasabi wishing it were only a faint kick! In my opinion, if the depth of wasabi flavor is not there, it really is just another bowl of tonkotsu ramen, with a hint of wasabi. I told the waitress who said she'd convey it to the chef, so maybe there will be a slight change next time?On the other hand, the ramen had veerry good noodles. I am a big fan of thin straight ramen noodles (as opposed to curly or flat ones). These were straight, firm, and a little chewy, which to me is an example of well-made ramen noodles. It's always easy to make it too soggy and I don't enjoy it when it's bordering that opaque look, but as I said, these were firm chewy tender noodles with great flavor. They were very yellow too, so these were probably made with a higher egg content, giving it that yellow hue and flavor that reminds me of Chinese egg noodles (but with nicer texture). Another pro was that the egg was pretty delicious as well. It's no "dayum..dayum..DAYUM" (see review on Bone Daddies on my usage of the Dayum scale) but still great execution. It was not as runny as I would like it but it wasn't overcooked and you can still see the soft, creamy, orangey glow in the middle. So the main difference was that it wasn't as beautifully runny like Bone Daddies' egg, but to me it was marinated to perfection and not overly salty as Bone Daddies' eggs. The same goes for the pork. They were not overwhelming large slices; in fact, I usually save the pork for the end and when I reached the end, in hindsight, I think I only got one slice total? It was either one slice or one and a half slices. Not the most protein one could wish for but it was tasty. And I was too busy wolfing down my noodles anyways. Lastly, Shoryu Ramen doesn't have a bar area for one-person parties (is it a party if there's only one person :( ?). I always think ramen joints should keep with tradition to have single seats, for those who want to sidle in for a quick eat. That's the true beauty of eating ramen like fast-food as they do in Japan! Instead, they have a couple of small tables, and a long booth seat along the wall with small tables to section parties off. Meh, guess I'll just have to find some friends to come with!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Wasabi Tonkotsu

Re4a0mnuSwjpPjyvxZJ2Xg.text: It did hit a spot! We are visiting London for the first time and found this place. We were so happy because our 4 year old daughter finished her bowl! She likes eating good ramen.

4kdFuoZtFE9q2lAMqJvTtQ.text: I've become a regular here since I first came 2 years ago. It's one of our go to restaurants when we're in central London (which is almost daily). It's always busy but we rarely have to wait for a seat for more than 10mins - service is fast and food is always amazing. I'd say this is my favourite ramen place above others such as Bone Daddies, Koya or Tonkotsu. I think the broth and noodle have the best texture/consistency/flavour out of them all! We also go to the Shoryu in King Street but this is still my favourite one.

oVN_zv53rMURd8gK4nfW_A.text: Had a great bowl of Ramen hear a couple days back. Was really craving some good quality ramen after all the cold and the rain this week in London. I came on a weekday afternoon around 4pm, it was pretty empty at that time and I was seated immediately.I ordered the special Hakata Tonkotsu ramen with spicy ground pork. It was very rich and flavorful. I could really taste the good quality of each of the ingredients, and then broth had a very unique taste compared to other ramen broths I've had.Service and ambiance were good, no complaints as I did come at an off peak time.I would recommend this place for good quality, flavorful ramen!

envc89gCwserU330dprWnQ.text: So I was with someone who's been here before and after a rather long debate, this place seemed to be one of the few places that are open late (up to London standards that is). The ambience was nice and the decor as per the usual ramen bar (no Bone Daddies rockability theme here).The food seemed rather adventurous for a ramen place - an interesting mix of flavours with funky names. It did take some time for it to arrive at the table (especially given the fact that everyone was leaving by the time we got there).Anyway, pretty good food, matching that generally offered in London. I've ordered the Tokyo Shoryu.  The broth was fine, the noodles tasted rather good and he toppings were OK, just your typical japanese inspired out-of-the-tin vegetables with meat. Soft shell crab was rather soggy, but I wasn't expecting any miracles here.What was excruciatingly horrible was the service. Yes, we turned up late and our food was late. However when I discovered a hair in my food I got extremely upset by the fact that no one had the courage to come to me and apologise/offer a refund as they usually do in such places. I hadn't touched more than half of my food and no response - extremely unprofessional and definitely not what one would expect from such a central London location. I saw the floor manager who was only able to offer an apology and had the service charge taken - something that I found rather disrespectful for both the staff and I as the service was generally good.I don't know if I'd go back - possibly I'd try the other branch but this place needs to invest more on customer care.

eL8TjznkmoHMm98_R1LiyA.text: Hot bowl of ramen = Perfect remedy for a freezing cold London day! Had to queue outside for about a half hour to get a table for two, but that was expected and so worth it. Something that stood out to me and I just have to mention it, is that they have a heat lamp for all of us eager ramen-craving freezing patrons right outside of the entrance. How thoughtful :) We started with the pork belly hirata buns. The bread was fluffy and the meat was tender, delicious. A little bit of spiciness, which was unexpected but tolerable enough for a spice-wimp like me. Then came the main event. I had the Tokyo Shoyu and it was amazing. The broth was full of flavour and the pork, veggies & noodles were all delectable. The portion was enormous and I was fully stuffed and satisfied at the end of the meal. Great place!

vOsF8rDJUOq_vCE6fJWpKg.text: Pretty good food.  Looks nice and clean.  I wish there was a bit more variety in the ingredients and types of meats.  I'd probably go there again, primarily because there's a lack of good restaurants in this part of town.

imU2nZ0OkIJG0zwx6DHHdA.text: The best ramen shop in all of Europe! Proper-est!! The noodle and the soup are authentic and good. But my ramen was served rather lukewarm. :(

BRFTJzlaCL4gXBQE4fKCeg.text: Damn fine ramen of the creamy tonkotsu variety which would merit 4 stars but for the terrible service.  Waiters and the manager seemed to ignore our eye contact and repeated polite hand signals, so I had to get up from the table to ask for a menu.  After another several hand signals we were able to order, and received our food after yet another delay.  Unless you're desperate for ramen (no shame in that), I'd recommend avoiding it.

qAVfsyIHlcB9aSbRcCjvmQ.text: At first I thought it's a good place to bring friends there, showing them Japanese food style, but the problem is I only ordered one set but the restaurant charged me extra one , that's 22pounds! And no one remind me there is something wrong with that!

Muij7caZs5-PlwSKRBr7Rg.text: I'm gonna give this place a 3 unfortunately as they kept messing up our bun order (it arrived 3 times!). Also, I asked for some spicy sauce and they chargd me £1 for it. If it wasn't free (which it should be in a ramen place) then at least give a heads-up to the customer so they can decide.

2vFb9xInH7ZyttKbrBKSwg.text: Must try!! The service was great and the food was excellent! My new favorite ramen place in London! Shoutout to Georgia our waitress for being awesome! :)

2EXZ4YmRjCqGLJlpO6_Big.text: After watching a certain Youtuber rave about this place, I decided to go check it out. Unfortunately, the taste was not as spectacular as the way the Youtuber sold it-- or maybe we just have different taste buds. The spicy ramen was not that spicy. It didn't have a particular "kick" to it. It was too bland. The vegan option was interesting because the broth was made of soy. I got the original. It was good but it wasn't something that stood out to me. The meat, tho, blew me away. It just melted into my mouth when I took the first bite. Overall, the service was great and the food wasn't bad! It's just that I've had better in my day.

VQPGDuG4vQt-i8BWrL_tdQ.text: I love ramen on chilly nights and that's where we headed after church on a Sunday evening. We got seated fairly quickly, although by the door. We found out how odd that was after we went to washroom and found the entire back of the house empty. Oh well. The food was delicious, hearty and warming to the belly. I got the spicy ramen and it was a little spicier than I anticipated but yummy nonetheless. The only thing I'd say I don't like is that the portions are smaller than any other ramen restaurant I've been to and the prices are a tiny bit higher, so the value isn't quite there. Usually, I have difficulty finishing my portion but I probably could've eaten a few more bites after I was done this time. Maybe don't come if you're starving but it's a good small meal if you're not terribly famished.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Piri piri ramen

XPtSjmQAqAJxDS8N7iTHDg.text: Not the biggest fan of the soup that they use but the noodles are good. Their curry dishes are pretty good and for Japanese food the price is decent. However the service at this place is pretty bad. Very slow to respond so be prepared to wait 15-20min for them to even get some drinks.

TJTCCW7vGFMqx_7x7tZ2Pg.text: I'm kind of disappointed at this restaurant. First, I waited 45 minutes to eat ramen at around 9pm on Saturday night. They say they are recommended by Michelin in different years but I don't seem to find them on the Michelin website. I tried the recommended Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu ramen. I'm so disappointed. The soup is not think, the meat is bland, the egg is bland. They say they marinate the pork and egg for a long time but they don't taste like that. The takoyaki is different from the ordinary ones as they are deep fried. So it's crispy outside. It's £6.9 for 5 pieces but in each one, there's only a tiny piece of octopus. The rest is just dough. It doesn't worth the price. It doesn't worth the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Drink menu
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Takoyaki
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu ramen

uTukDgAy852jJVZf7YOmTg.text: The best ramen I had in London so far! This place is amazing if you want to try the original ramen and feel the taste of the rich broth they made. I've ordered the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu and was amazing! from the broth to the pork and the noodles were just perfect. You can also choose how you want the noodles to be cooked (from standard to soft to hard). Portion was big enough, staff is nice and friendly, place is not too loud so you can enjoy a chat before and after. This place is also located in a nice spot: not far from Piccadilly circus but not in the heart oh Soho = no queue! That made our Thursday dinner perfect!If I want to be super picky  (as I am,unfortunately) the only cons is: only one toilet for the entire restaurant!You will see people queuing  in front of it which is not great as it is close to the tables so if you are not lucky enough to be close to the bathroom you could end up with people behind you queuing for the loo. Apart from that, great experience and great food!Will definitely come back soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

icwz8nR8KkbMBgnEDI5BhA.text: First time and the ramen is delicious and the service is good.  The drinks are superb.  Very happy customer!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Goyosa
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Love Takoyaki!
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Simply amazing!!!

lPMWHXhdDXGlUkjO4vGYog.text: The wait was long and they left us in the cold outside!The staff gave us the wrong information about the Valentine's menu and forgot my order!The worst was the supervisor who ignore our calls and pretended we didn't exist. Only saving grace was the ramen which was nice.Will not recommend becoz of terrible service. The Japanese way has been totally ruined by the supervisor.

b2wWArQy9ow9lE0vFoT2xw.text: I've been to Kanadaya, Bone Daddies, and other ramen places but this is my favorite! Had the thicker broth version of tonkotsu ramen, and the soup was thick and flavorful. The noodles are went perfectly with the broth ! (Which wasn't the case for some other ramen restaurants) The waiters and waitresses are also very welcoming and nice :)

u-Yvlg7bHHCQrYlo1WH0yw.text: A lovely place with a good and fast service.It was fully booked when we we there, but we got a fast service.We took two ramen, one of them was vegetarian. And two buns to taste with cheese was perfect and with shrimps was less tasty. But overall I'll recommend this place.

pTtCu4nAUS7MNp064GkQBg.text: Came here via Yelp late at night 23:00 and it did not disappoint. Service was friendly and the food was great. Ordered Salt and Pepper chicken which was hot and crispy, Waygu Beef Bun and BBQ Bun and they were delicious- especially the Waygu. Also had the Curry ramen and it was tasty (not as spicy as I would like but very good anyway). The only "negative" thing was the drum - they hit it twice for every party that came in or left. But not annoying enough to not rate this tasty place a five star.

pW5aFaO9PIEhJHWjoj8MSg.text: One of the best tonkotsu ramen in town. Highly recommended! They beer range is also very good. Polite and informative staff, decent prices and nice atmosphere. I like the fact that this chain keeps expanding in London!

y3RGzlBQzeG7IAJtUVA6kw.text: I was actually at the location at Carnaby St. and when I went to go check this place out on yelp, I didn't realize that Shoryu was a small franchise and that there were several locations around London. The place on Carnaby St was small, but cozy and pretty lively on a Sunday night. I was seated at the booth and started to chat up with the bartenders. It was my first time, so they explained that they specialize in tonkotsu ramen and went through the pretty large menu with a lot of different ramen options and side dishes. I decided on the Kimchi Seafood tonkotsu because I love spice. I was also able to customize the texture of my ramen (standard, hard, super hard) which I thought was interesting as I have never had that option given to me before. I also got gyoza (because obviously you should get that with every ramen dish) as well as a steamed pork belly bun to start. Also, if you like lychee, definitely try the pink lychee jasmine tea, you won't regret it! The steamed bun came on the mini wooden steamer which I thought was super cute and the pork belly was super flavourful and the bun was also very soft and delicious. The gyoza I absolutely loved!! The crispy layer on the dumping as well as the filling were SO good and not overly salty. I definitely wish I ordered more. The ramen itself was definitely good, but I found the broth to be standard and definitely not as spicy as I wished it to be. It was very mild. I loved that they were very generous on the seafood and I had a lot of it in my ramen. Great sized portion and reasonably priced! While it wasn't busy, I found the service to be a little slow. Overall, I was pretty happy with the place and I probably would return if I could!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly steamed bun w/ pink lychee jasmine tea drink
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Gyoza - should've gotten more! So good!
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Kimchi Seafood Ramen

TtWV3gf_jdYo60nBZWnLWw.text: Michelin Guide "recommended" my ass. Six hours after eating I woke up all nauseous in the middle of the night. Proceeded to rush into the bathroom with mud butt diarrhea and then vomit. Aside from the bout of foodborne illness I'm currently experiencing, the food was less than mediocre at best. This was my first time here and I ordered the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu. The tonkotsu broth is nothing to write home about (incredibly bland for boasting that it takes 12 hours to cook), the chashu was flavorless, and the noodles were... well, comparatively similar to everything else that's supposedly good about their ramen. When the ramen was brought out, the broth and egg were cold but the noodles were hot. At the end, I couldn't bring myself to finish the bowl and that's rare as I normally devour ramen instantly.Overall, 10/10 would AVOID this place like the bubonic plague.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Don't let this picture deceive you. Almost had to replace the toilet from violent diarrhea.
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Michelin Guide "recommended". Yeah right.

ZpJqpOtdYN9SjRY7y3dGMg.text: I've been coming to Shoryu for years so this recent visit was extremely disappointing because I am familiar with their usual level of service and quality of food. When I was seated I sat there for maybe ten minutes before I had to ask someone for a menu, while other parties were sat after me and given menus right away. These same parties were also given the opportunity to order before I was. I made eye contact with several waiters, signaling that I was ready to order and they ignored me, continuing to chat to each other behind the counter. It wasn't until another ten minutes that I was given the opportunity to order. I ordered my usual prawn tempura shoryu bun and a piri piri tonkotsu. When the shoryu bun comes out, there is usually a wrapped wet wipe so that you can clean your hands before you pick up the bun but they didn't give me anything and I had difficulty getting anyone's attention again so I just gave up and ate the bun which tasted great, as usual. When my tonkotsu came out, the nitamago was really overdone to where there was no runny yolk quality, and about 90% of the yolk was a crumbling yellow rather than a silky orange. When I asked for another egg, the waitress asked what was wrong with it and I told her it was overdone and how it's supposed to be soft boiled (I had to explain to her what a proper nitamago looks like while I'm sitting in front of a chalkboard with the definitions of the different elements that make up a ramen, one of which is a definition of a nitamago). She came back with another egg that was still over cooked but better than the my initial egg claiming "this is the best we've got".  Other than the egg, the ramen was delicious. Finally, when I asked for my check they brought me the bill right away and I sat with my credit card in my hand for maybe 15 minutes before I had to again ask if I could pay. A new waitress came and asked if I wanted to pay by card, and I asked her if the 12.5% service charge could be taken off because out of all the years I've been here I've never experienced such awful service. She just sulked away and came back with an adjusted bill, not once making an attempt to ask why I felt that way or inquire as to what they could do to improve. She merely processed my transaction in complete silence and then walked away. I would also like to add that I was not the only one experiencing poor customer service. There was a six-top of Australian diners behind me who asked for water from at least three different waiters and also said they were ready to order, to which the waitress who processed my bill replied in a really harsh and rude tone "it's coming! I've already asked!" And another waiter turned up and told them "you're just going to have to wait!"I usually go to the carnaby branch so maybe it's my mistake for going to a different location but I've been to this location in the past too. I don't think I will return to this branch but look forward to going to another branch soon

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Although an improvement from the first one, it definitely isn't as silky as a nitamago should be.

T4aloLuELOPHu0_AK030iw.text: We went to a Japanese restaurant in soho and found it shut earlier this evening. It may been closed due to the bank holiday plus gumball 3000 was on in regent street. We ended up walking round and found this place! I went in to ask for a table for three and was told it was bout 15 min wait, and the queue was outside, as no room inside to stand! They do have a heater outside so it's not too bad. When we got our table, they explained how the menu worked with the different styles of noodle and the bun offer where you can get 2 for 1 if you order ramen noodles.We decided to try the buns, and ordered one pork one and a chicken one. We each had noodles and two of us ordered an extra half boiled egg each. You can have the noodles al dente, standard or soft. The original ramen dish was nice, I really liked the egg, it was soft boiled.I had a mocktail strawberry kusu mojito which was very refreshing. The place is small, but looks great, the staff are nice though we found our waitress a little hard to understand and had to go back and ask her what she meant.My friend did order more buns to take home to her husband as they were nice.

IgyeMx0cxq-tK1N1a0iQAQ.text: Wow! It was a toss up between here and Bone Daddies and we settled on this beauty. Being relatively new to Ramen I was excited to try another place and another type.We arrived and had to wait 10 minutes for a table. Be warned: You do have to wait outside for tables so maybe not the best option if freezing or raining but we were happy to wait as it was a mild night and it smelt so god damn good!We were seated on a long bench by the wall, at first we were a bit disappointed not to have a proper table but in the end we quite enjoyed it.We ordered the gyoza and pork and prawn buns to share. Then I ordered the curry ramen in the others section.The sides came first which I was glad about being staring. The gyoza was freshly cooked and mouth-wateringly good. The pieces of meat inside were chunky and they just went down a treat!Now, to the buns, it was the first time I'd ever had a 'bun' and I absolutely LOVED them. Whatever that weird type foldy bread is, it's amazing and the toppings were superb. I particularly liked the belly pork! NOW.Next, the ramen. Gosh it was good - garlic, curried soupy goodness with bites sized pieces of friend chicken breast, veg, seaweed and egg floating within. Just perfection. The curry had an almost katsu taste to it which I enjoyed and with the extra clove of garlic, I was in a ramen dream. It was slightly salty but I am a fan of salt so no complaints here! Service was fantastic and the overall ambience of the restaurant is relaxed and warming. We left full, satisfied and saying we'd definitely be back again.Happy Saturday!

nUYDTxKxhn5Vy7mMFKgCRA.text: A few days ago, I came across this busy and surprisingly delicious Japanese cafe. JV8da9M2IBq8uJTW-3FBAg.text: We looking for a a quick noodle fix before our train back to Birmingham. This looked liked the go to place for ramen and it didn't disappoint. Up on arrival into the small restaurant a bong sounded and all the staff greeted us in unison. A unique if not strange touch. The two of us had traveling bags, so chose a 4 seater table. Even this was a squeeze. I went for the shoryu pork ramen and my partner went for the curry flavoured chicken ramen. we had pork buns on the side to share. The dishes came quickly and were well presented. I really enjoyed the pork broth and the slowed cooked egg was perfect. The pork buns though seemed a little unloved and a bit thrown together. Overall a decent quick cheap eat.

xerjg6cXclF6QR0uPOGLjA.text: Although I personally prefer a simple tonkotsu ramen, they have quite the variety for those that are more adventurous. I found the overall experience and food better here than Bone Daddies. The fried chicken at Bone Daddies is better though!The Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu broth was rich and flavorful. dpOd-5WwXjOo6-x-OJvKYA.text: That is a decent Ramen like the one I'm used to find in California. I had the classic one with Pork, mushrooms and the half cooked egg. Ordered and Served promptly, Finished the bowl in a couple of minutes. Even Forgot to take a picture! I will go back there anytime!

UWdFuHmvTtLp1pVrmstYnw.text: Stopped by on a cold London afternoon to some comfort food. The wait staff was very welcoming, walking me through the menu and different options. I ordered their Tonkotsu ramen, gyoza and pork bun. I thought all of the food was very average, but not bad. The tonkotsu broth lacked something, but it was not flavorful enough while the noodles were a bit soft for my taste. Not a bad bowl of ramen but not one that is memorable. The gyoza was presented on a sizzling skillet, very cool. However, the flavor of the gyoza stuffing was also lacking something, perhaps sesame oil? The pork bun used a miso paste of some sort and was my least favorite thing I ordered that day. Okay for a quick bowl if you're craving one but probably not one I would recommend people to go out of their way to get. They do have free wifi.

TvWP2IGZ6aZrEYSXmU2ziw.text: This is not a Japanese ramen. I ordered chicken ramen and the taste was bland and my friend ordered pork based ramen but he said it tastes so bland. The price is expensive, there is no Japanese thing in this resto and the matcha taste bitter, it is like cheapest matcha which you can find in supermarket. I used to stay in Osaka Japan, and my descendant is Japanese, I know exactly this is not made by Japanese hand. They also asked for tips which makes it worst.

zSqT6wye0bCsr4z_o0n0hQ.text: An absolute favorite Ramen restaurant of mine. This was the first time I'd been to the Carnaby Street branch, tucked away inside Kingly Court. From all the Shroyus it has the best atmosphere by far! It's not as crowded/ small as the others, the wood-paneled walls give it a warm feel and the lighting and decor is just right. The food of course is amazing. We shared the pimentos and the Chicken Karaage (a definite MUST at Shoryu), and for our mains I had the Curry Ramen- bursting with flavor and totally filling, while my friend, who likes her dishes a little more spicy, chose the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu.Service was attentive and speedy, place was buzzing with people. You can't go wrong with this place to fulfill your Ramen Needs!

N-2P3eDFkAbZwyj1tTEQ7A.text: Really not that great. I was pretty disappointed in the overall experience. Ramen broth was ok but the meat wasn't seasoned well. Over crowded an bathroom smell was noticeable. This is tourist ramen.

paTO3RlA9yGu3u1aXvL2kg.text: Let me say that I'm a big ramen fan, but I think I've been spoiled by ramen I've had in San Francisco and Las Vegas.  On a cold rainy day in London ramen is a nice antidote to blah weather.  This place does a decent job, although the noodles were pretty thin and didn't seem to be freshly made.  Overall a decent place that I'd probably go back to.

ma-33qVecUXHOIBjhiRU3w.text: Came here after seeing it on yelp. I was having a crazy ramen craving and this seemed like a legit spot, so I gave it a try. I'm sure glad I did!I came at about 5 PM on a weekday and the place was about half full. I was immediately greeted by the waitstaff and seated at the tables facing the window (one of the perks of dining alone- you can people watch!). Its on Regent Street, smack dab in between Piccadilly Circus and Trafalgar Square so there's plenty of foot traffic going by. The restaurant is somewhat small but has a very modern-style Japanese decor theme. The menu is short and sweet, but they have plenty of varieties of ramen for every taste. I originally leaned towards the curry ramen but ultimately went with the piri-piri ramen after reading peoples' rave reviews. I put in my order for a cocktail (only £6 during happy hour!) and ramen, and both were out within 10 minutes. My cocktail -whose name I cannot remember- tasted like a mai tai and was definitely strong... but enjoyable. The ramen came out piping hot with lots of goodies on top of the bed of noodles. The noodles were cooked to the perfect al-dente consistency but I was a little disappointed in the lack of spiciness. Since this is their spicy option, I expected a little more of a kick. There was also a little bit too much lemongrass for my own personal tastes but not so much that it kept me from enjoying my meal. I noticed some reviews remarked on the small serving size but I felt it was the perfect size. I hadn't eaten all day and finished off most of my noodles, and felt more than satisfied. Overall, this is a great ramen place if you're in central London. The service was super friendly and attentive. The ramen itself was really tasty and they have all kinds of varieties to try. I definitely think its worth checking out if you get the chance!

dFlV6Ppzihqic9yIMEFijA.text: Yes, it's as good as advertised. Line is not that long. And it's nice that they have a nice heat lamp for those waiting outside.

9L43KnWCzwHvGzVNvL4uDw.text: As a ramen junkie from NYC, I've been traveling around London's ramen scene to try and find the best bowl here. Shoryu piqued my interest due to the fact that they tout their Hakata roots, which is the region of Japan that tonkotsu ramen is specialized. So I had to come by and try the tonkotsu broth!I stopped in around noon and was seated immediately. I ordered the Kotteri Tonkotsu Ramen, a chashu pork bun, and a grilled halloumi and shimeji mushroom bun.The ramen came out first, which was a bit strange, but I started eating. The broth was not as rich as I like my tonkotsu ramen to be. It has what I've complained about most NYC ramen - I call it the "Ippudo Problem," where the tonkotsu broth is the specialty but is not super rich. Tonkotsu broth should be thick, bony, and hearty, but the broth here (which was said to be extra rich) is pretty thin. Also, it was a bit under seasoned, a bit bland. I don't like my broths salty but I do like some flavor in the soup.The noodles here are missing that signature bite that ramen noodles have (even when I ordered it hard), almost just like regular egg noodles.You can thank Momofuku and David Chang for the steamed buns with ramen trend around the world, and the buns here have the same problem that the ones at Momofuku Noodle Bar in NYC does - they are overly sauced with a very strong sauce that masks the flavor of the main ingredient and you basically are eating a bao with sauce and some meat/protein rather than getting a nice complex bite of flavors and textures. It's a shame, because I only really tasted the cucumber because it was not as salty as the rest of it. I actually had to wash it down with the broth (really shows you how bland it was).I ordered kaedama and it came out quickly, but they didn't put any tare or sauce on the noodles, so when I put it into the bowl, it watered it down a bit and made it blander.Overall, this was a pretty average bowl of ramen. There are many better bowls of ramen in London.

0o7RRVJpRS6KdqS0mploGg.text: I'll go here again.  Small place but packed with lots of flavor and great Japanese ramen.  I got their set (shoryu bun, ramen, and cheesecake for 11.90) and Kirin Frozen. Great meal for dinner.

AY4MTDe9Lm6pTg0jZ7v-oQ.text: I almost always try the most basic ramen when I visit a new place, but this time I made an exception and went for one of my favorites, cold sesame ramen (Hiyashi Chuka). If you've never had this before, and it's a hot summer day, you should definitely give it a chance. Save the hot soup for colder weather.Noodles: Very good. Firm and cooked just right. Better than Bone Daddies IMO.Hiyashi Chuka sauce/tare: A bit to much sweetness, but overall very good.Tokyo egg: Perfectly cooked. However Bone Daddies tea smoked marinated egg is still one of the best I've ever had anywhere. Toppings: Menma (bamboo) not bad, needed  more crunch. Tomatoes were not the best - since they're in season now they could have been better. Charsu was a bit to dry, that's why most places use cooked ham typically (there  is no hot soup to soften the chasu). Nit picking now: Needed a small dab of mustard on the side (pretty standard). And cucumbers should be added too - especially since you're making it in England where they love cucumber too.Overall: A great bowl. In Tokyo I'd give it a 3, but for London it's top notch.Other stuff: Service was decent, but I find it really weird in London how so many servers don't seem to know squat about the food they're serving. Gyoza were good - and may have been made in house possibly (impressive).I will return to try the basic tonkatsu ramen when the weather changes.
