Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Chilled ramen or hiyashi chukka.

n63CA3uz1kRl0b8FKcQJgQ.text: Very tasty and mouthful. Stick with the raman, everything else is ordinary. Staff are pleasant ans the decor is nice.

NfpHDbapxxarWk9WE5R7hg.text: Try to get here before 6pm if you are dining on a Saturday evening or you'll have to wait in line outside!I too think their tonkotsu ramen is better than Bone Daddy's.  I had a bite of the ramen with matcha noodle, but I personally like the regular noodle better taste-wise, less distraction from the rest of the dish.  And matcha noodle seems to get soft quickly in hot soup while the regular noodle stayed firm for long.I was very impressed with their salmon Hirata Buns.  The salmon karaage goes really with the soft bun with lettuce and cucumber, really enjoyed it :)If you are looking for a Ume-shou type of salty tea, their Ume Kombu Cha is recommended.

pLa2MEsiabMu3fCxny4LcQ.text: Ramen in london.  After visiting japan, the ramen was average.   Nothing bad about it although it it took an awful long time to arrive to the table.  The servers were really nice.   The price i felt was too high compared to other competitors.

DAoXuq1oH7LvzM_9NKvW9Q.text: I don't want to sound like a food snob, but I wasn't expecting much from an English ramen place. However, I'm happy to say that Shoryu was a pleasant surprise! I saw a bunch of people waiting on line to get in but they were in parties of 3+ so I decided to go in and put myself on a list in case there was one. Turns out there is no list, the line is 'first come first served' but because I told them that I was just two people, we got to skip the line. Lesson: don't just follow the crowd. As per usual in London, it took a million years for them to take our order of a beer, cocktail, the tan tan ramen and the Dracula ramen. The cocktail, which was just soda and plum wine, wasn't very good. But, the ramens weren't all that bad. The minced pork ramen (£10) was pretty much liquid fire for me, but my boyfriend managed fine. The Dracula ramen (£11.90) had a richer broth that wasn't spicy and was really good when I added some rice vinegar to it. Good spot if you're looking for a change from the fish and chips, but I don't need to go back.

X_Ae1D--bkSMJvsmQQhLmw.text: Really really good ramen place in the heart of London. It apparently was nominated for a Michelin star?! I've been to ramen everywhere in the States, and I have to tell you, this was some of the best I've ever had. We ordered the karaage and spicy mentaiko appetizers as well, which were wonderful. The karaage had the perfect amount of crunch and the mentaiko was delicious without being overbearing (p.s. add some soy sauce to this if you'd like!). The ramen noodles had good texture and the broth was perfect without being too salty or heavy. I honestly ended up drinking the entire bowl. The prices are very reasonable (€8 or so for a bowl) and honestly I'm sad we don't have one in the States. A must-stop place for ramen lovers.

Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. The recommended ramen

PR8vVZHdjRxtuiKIi_aF9A.text: Travelling from out of the country and needed to try some local ramen. I ordered the Piri Lori Tonkotsu - extra heat, jalapeños, and a secret spicy sauce. Overall I enjoyed the meal. The broth is definitely near the top of my list for the ramen I've tried, and spiciness was a slight kick without being overbearing. The pork was average, and could have used more flavoring and tenderness in my opinion. Variety of noodle selections as well with choices of varying chewiness.The location itself was nice, with a tendency for couples or intimate dinners, but options for mid-sized and individual stool seating as well. All the staff were very friendly.Unfortunately they were out of the frozen Kirin when I went, but would definitely be interested in trying if I get the chance to return.

pQruaYTyX_GXnd7Cw_do6g.text: Ramen is one of my favourite foods to go out to eat, especially back in my hometown of Vancouver where there is certainly no shortage of ramen shops! Since moving to London, I've tried both Ippudo and Shoryu a few times, trying to figure out which one I liked more, and I've come to the conclusion that the broth at Shoryu is definitely tastier. The Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu is fantastic here (the broth, the noodles, and the charsiu all taste great). Sprinkle on some sesame seeds and garlic, and your bowl will taste even better! Service here has also been consistently good, even when the restaurant is busy. My only minor complaint is that their ramen eggs aren't as good as what I've had elsewhere (strangely they seem less flavourful?), but still not bad. Certainly not a big enough complaint to detract from the rest of the dish.I really don't have much else to say that the other 200+ reviews here haven't already said. Shoryu is probably my favourite ramen shop in London, and I will definitely return!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu

kGNwEXgmSaW1jtloo_Pz_A.text: Are you serious? Ridiculously good ramen and we've had great ramen! There's a reason this place is 3x Michelin recommended. This takes the great ramen we have had and bumps it into gourmet. Even what seemed like a boring choice, the origin tonkatsu, was surprisingly amazing, full of flavor. My 8 & 10 yo kids left nothing behind. (And they know their ramen.) I had the tan tan ramen as I always order at ramen houses and the egg is organic as evidence by the super orange yolk. The broth had depth and complexity. They use bones and you can tell. We were here on Monday so we got the 2for1 bun deal. The prawn buns were the real deal prawn size! The buns were large too, big enough to hold the prawns. The only complaint is that the buns took a long time to come out.

2xNZOuKJstqWZBJDkobZIg.text: It seems like Shoryu Ramen is quite a big name in London, they got the restaurant in couple places. I hadn't heard that yet till when I was in London with my hubby. We were hungry for Asian cuisine, the Shoryu Ramen was one of the few which close to us. Since we both like Ramen, so we decided to head to this one. The restaurant was quite close to Piccadilly Circus and located right on the main street, so quite easy for us to find it. Inside the place was also really nice, It gave me a really nice feeling, the place is clean and modern but also got a Japanese culture in it. Although the restaurant wasn't big, we just like it here. When we were here, it was quite busy. It is always a good sign for a good restaurant. And luckily they were still managed a table for two for us, that was nice. After we sat down, we got a look of the menu, wow, lots of nice food in there, I would like to order. Well, I just wanted to try out the Ramen here first. And I forgot that outside of Germany, it is quite common that restaurant will gave free water on the table. We ordered extra drinks, well, got more options anyway. I really like the Ramen here, it tasted really good. But again still something was missing compared those I had tried back in Asia, I couldn't really tell what. But again it tasted still really great. I got the idea why this place was well-known here. The price was alright, quite reasonable. I did remember that will recommend to give tips 18%, that was quite a bit much, I think. There was also WIFI in the restaurant, quite convenient for people who need it.

z8kF-CfHUJQwJuRRWqCVqg.text: Delicious! Server wasn't the most knowledgeable or confident but the ramen more than made up for it.

WcqVokD3UIZgBK-ULOfjdQ.text: Having lived in NYC and LA, I've had some pretty bomb-ass ramen and unfortunately this just didn't match up. I had the most popular tonkotsu ramen  with supposedly extra rich broth. However, I had to add a little more chili oil and soy sauce than I would have liked in order to make it more flavorful. It wasn't terrible but it also wasn't the best and I'm not sure that I'd return. On the positive side, the guy who brought us our water was really nice and friendly :)

nEC7CEZ3JW7131PvCMRZ5Q.text: Pretty good ramen - not on par with Ippudo but overall pretty good.Space is super small (cozy) - you'll be sitting shoulder to shoulder with other customers. There wasn't a wait when I went but since the place is small - I wouldn't be surprised if there was one. The pork belly buns were just ok - they put way too much mayo in the buns which took away from the pork belly itself. I'd suggest omitting the mayo all together.The cucumber dish was alright - just a small cucumber with some sesame oil and hot flakes on top - super bland. It would have been so much better with a little vinegar.The ramen itself was good - decent portions - toppings were limited and expensive for extras. The noodles were cooked well as was the poached egg. Soup was flavorful and came with good slices of pork. Service was nice and friendly. There is free wifi which is always a plus!Decent place to get your ramen fix - prices are ok for the city - about £40 for a meal for 2

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Original tonkotsu

KPervC-CQ5rFA6TnKfmkyQ.text: One of the better ramen places I've been to in the world, I stumbled upon it accidentally while returning some keys to a friend - proof that there's a silver lining in everything.The first thing you should know is that this place gets very busy, so you might need to wait a bit. The second thing is that the waiters are going to explain the entire menu to you if you say you've never been there before, down to every last detail. It's kind of patronizing.I love spicy ramen and will almost always pick it over the others. Their menu lists a traditional tonkatsu, but then it also lists a Kotteri Hakata Tonkatsu ramen that has a richer and thicker sauce. There was an unnecessary amount of confusion when I asked if the spicy Piri Piri Tonkatsu was made with the traditional tonkatsu, or the Kotteri - the waitress explained to me what tonkatsu was three times in a row. So I just ordered it.If you like spicy ramen, the Piri Piri is the way to go. The broth was smooth and silky and had just enough heat to make your forehead sweat a little, but not enough to burn your tastebuds into oblivion. The noodles were perfect, smooth and not overdone. I didn't like that they added raw jalapeno and ginger though. The ginger kind of threw off the rest of the flavor and I avoided the jalapeno because I didn't want my mouth to catch on fire.If you're in London and have a ramen craving then this is your place. Just be prepared to wait and/or be spoken to as if you were a child.

t64xAcrLBrGvvOCeV7arWw.text: I got the special saki flight and the tonkoysu bowl. Perfect flavours. The saki flight at 12 pound was worth the price, it was basically three double shot glasses full of the best saki brand you can buy.

teo68ckEsTs22K0G1RjcuA.text: The ramen had lots of flavor and was a very big portion.  The pork buns were a little small but the pork was delicious. The scallions and red ginger give the ramen a fresh taste while adding heat. There is white pepper. A sesame seed grinder. Hot oil and  sauce to add to your ramen. They only thing that was annoying is they had a gong that was very loud and they banged it every time someone came in.

DDBiqLJRTQ9B7_XgTdyVSg.text: Great ramen place. We came late on a Thursday night and the place was still busy with a nice atmosphere. We started off with a chicken bun each first -- they were great. A thick pancake with cucumber and hoisin sauce with a nice big piece of fried chicken in it. Next we both had a ramen dish, I had the recommended Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu -- which was a nice filling dish. We also had the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu, which was similar to my dish but spicy -- it was really good. If you like spicy food I'd chose this dish over the other one. A nice meal out, about £12 for a bowl of ramen. Not to bad of prices, seen though it's right down the street from Piccadilly Circus. Easy walk to and from the tube.

kGC9zIA5FAFaOlQ51_-m2Q.text: Um, no again.This place was just as bad as Kanada-Ya but for different reasons. The tonkotsu ramen was so bad we couldn't finish it. The pork buns were smothered in sauce we couldn't finish those either.

Xvtg1CJndmnPcBNL7RZQLA.text: Wish I could give this place a 3.5+ Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu was pretty tasty. Broth was thick and rich. Slightly too salty for my taste but overall well done. The noodles were fantastic and with firmness cooked to order. Pork pieces were nothing special, but the egg was better than most. LZiTBBJiOFFLNbQoE-pdug.text: I'm only giving it 4 stars because I don't know sh*te from shinola when comes to Raman BUT this place was really good.  It was 2 for the price of 1 bun Monday when my son and I stopped in - Bun-tastic was the phase used, bonus points for that.!!!My son ordered the Gyoza - He loved 'em.  I ordered the raman with pork as well as the pork bun with the chicken bun; all of the above was fantastic.

aTTCPhfN9Asdkrer3SaWww.text: Incredible ramen!! Kids loved the gyoza (potstickers) and chicken Kaarage (like nuggets)!

S3ZtkQPgVYXyDBlPa6sW_g.text: I love this place!!!! Great value for money, staff is very nice, quick service and ramen are just delicious here! My fav is white natural with super hard noodles! A must try is the black sesame tofu!

6rxiNDysDWYArU8kIf0GFA.text: Having been spoiled silly this year with highly anticipated trips to both Ippudo (yelp.com/biz/ippudo-ny-n…) and Momofuku (yelp.com/biz/momofuku-no…) over in New York city, I was thrilled to see what the city of London had to offer in terms of pork buns and ramen. Behold: Shoryu. The verdict? Better than Momofuku Noodle Bar, but just shy of Ippudo.Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?One thing I will say regarding the atmosphere is that Shoryu does an excellent job of walking the fine line between authentic and fusion. Many of the staff are clearly japanese, but the atmosphere is such that you'll be comfortable even if you're a local or a non-Japanese tourist. Seating is both varied and abundant, so you'll be good whether you're a larger party of just an individual like I was. While the ramen can take a bit of time to come out, know that's because it's made to order, and in the meantime you can dig into a pork bun, which you absolutely should. Star Granted. Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?Prices here at Shoryu are comparable to what you'll find elsewhere, with everything inflated just a bit to adjust for currency. Ramen? Twelve pounds. A pork bun? Just shy of a fiver. Considering that these portions are sizable, these are fair prices across the board. Star Granted. Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?I went with a mix of traditional and contemporary here at Shoryu, and the result was a classic pork bun and a more modern 'Peri Peri' spicy ramen. I ended up with a bit of a mixed bag, with top notch ramen and a pork bun that was good but not what I would call elite. First? The pork bun. Good? Again, yes, this was a good pork bun, but I was a bit surprised at the simplicity of the auxiliary ingredients. The lettuce was standard iceberg, and while the pork was good, the entire thing was drowned in a chipotle mayo of some source that cleaned out a lot of the flavor. Good, but not the best I've had (that's you Ippudo). Now, the ramen I will say was easily top tier. I have a pretty exceptionally high tolerance for spicy food, so when I was warned that the peri peri ramen was spicy I more or less brushed it off. Wow. A word to the wise? This is some spicy ramen, and when it came down to drinking the broth I had to stop shy of finishing off the whole thing on account of my throat burning with jalapeno seeds. Having said that, the chicken and seaweed and egg and noodles were phenomenal, and this was pretty close to being on par with the best ramen I've had over at Ippudo.  Excellent. Single Star Granted. Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?While it's not the best ramen and pork bun combo I've ever had, for now Shoryu is the best I've found in the city, and that warrants a fourth star overall. Star Granted.

YlwxFe4QKVLtCOxql4Kurw.text: Shoryu was a solid place to get ramen. Everything was flavorful, but it did leave a bit to be desired. The buns were great, and the sake was authentic. The soup I got was good, and I liked the spicy sauce available on the table, but something was a bit off. Although the pork belly was good, it was obvious that it was not very fresh. It was seasoned well, but it shared a similar flavor with the turkey that you'd have a few days after thanksgiving. That being said, I had a good experience here and would definitely recommend going here.

vfUysABSlrM9nB9LbHhBsQ.text: This place is always busy and I definitely wasn't dissapointed once I had jostled for the last reminaing seat!I had the natural tonkotsu and my boyfriend had the iced chicken wings and pork buns, which he loved.The dumplings were a little on the dry side unfortunately but everything else was great.

BnhPcrORQ1QLKBGSshdg2A.text: Got to finally try this place out. Waited around 10mins to be seated during the lunch time hours. Ordered the Shoryu Ramen, and have to say I was impressed. Very good flavor broth and the veg was very good and the meat was cooked spot on. I pretty much gobbled up all of it and the egg was cooked perfectly. Obviously not as amazing as the Ramen I have in Los Angeles, but for London I was very happy with it. Definitely recommend this place for anyone craving Ramen around London.

kSUSaDpO8Kg9mFvI4AyaKw.text: Not bad for local standard, but lacks authenticity.  Soup base should be richer, the noodle is a bit too soggy for ramen gurus.

LKk3EfcgKEiSo9DjBF6KRg.text: Perfect place to be when its cold and wet outside. Ended up getting a spicy ramen which was incredible. Broth wasn't overpowered by the spice. We also got some bao/buns to share. Chicken came with an amazing sauce, the pork was maybe a little too fatty for my liking. (Visit - 27/05/2014 Dinner)

59cTIGC9784nWmWDPfkG9w.text: There are queues everywhere in London, but this one wasn't so bad when we arrived around 5:30pm on a Saturday (10 mins wait), and definitely worth it! This was my first real ramen house experience, so I got the tonkotsu regular - it was flavorful with an egg, veggies but only about three slices of pork. I had a taste of the spicy tonkotsu broth, and it's a little more flavorful only if you can handle the heat!! We also didn't have to wait very long for the soup to come, which was convenient. The ambiance is charming and modern, and the servers were attentive, but since this restaurant is quite small and pretty busy, we decided against overstaying our welcome. Recommended if you're near Piccadilly Circus.

I841EH9nREQwtBWX1SU8AA.text: lovely place. the waitress explains all the different types of ramen soup. the kotteri Hakkatan tonkotsu is to die for

5uvdI4uikE8OcEW3luv6EQ.text: This place is in the heart of the shopping district in London. After walking around in the cold throughout the day, my gf and I wanted something warm and came across this place. The service and location are exceptional, albeit a very touristy location. Obviously, I gravitated towards this location because all tourists get sucked into the "tourist epicenter" of any city. The food is good but not great (meat quality in the buns is not good) and definitely not worth the price. I understand rent is very expensive in this area and the high costs definitely pass down to the food. However, I was still disappointed with the quality of food based on the price. After paying for the meal, I thought about selling my semen to a sperm bank to help offset the cost of this meal. I eventually decided not to do it because I didn't want my biological kids trying to find me 30 years later during their "finding myself stage" to figure out what genetic similarities we shared. At the end of the day, I thought about semen for money for ramen. End of story. End of review. I didn't do it. I'm out.

89oYiZaL5F_OSCfhATHeTw.text: I give this 5 stars because it was just amazing. The menu had so many options and was super nutritious (even had multiple gluten-free options!) I tried the Hirata Bun first which was a rice bun with pork, lettuce, and an amazing sauce. The bun was so soft and the pork was really great. The service for the food was perfect, nice and fast. The standard origin Ramen I got after the Hirata bun was delicious!

2KDuSteyh8aQpONdz9fhvQ.text: Easily my favorite meal I've had in London. I thought about going back and definitely would have, but I wanted to try other places. I had to Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu which was fantastic.

Qaqs529Zpgvp4heOpOVyDg.text: Yummy! One star off because there was no healthy options. We got a bottle of rose and the buns with chicken karaage (deep fried). Then moved on to the chicken ramen which was better than the ramen I've had in the Bay Area even. Milky, flavourful and satisfying.  Again I wish they have grilled chicken so I could keep my diet but so yummy sometimes so worth it !

Anen1JaRMHBTQMvTuN3PoA.text: First sip was somewhat bland but after it felt a lot more creamy and flavourful for a tonkotsu ramen.Disagree with the Hirata Buns. Meat one was sub par compared to the many different buns offered using a japanese fusion take on things. The veggie one was different and actually special which pleased my vegetarian date.Overall not too bad. FxuzBjto_MlazGu5PU35lg.text: All their gluten free options were delicious - I could even eat shoryu buns again! Great for tourists and residents alike. It does seem to get crowded around peak times though.

2a8fYaDn9rATKsvlo0h5bQ.text: I came here on a rainy weekday at 5:30pm for linner and it was very empty. I guess everyone's off to the pubs at this time of the day. I decided to order the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu (minced pork) for a change and my friend ordered the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu. After tasting my Karaka Tan Tan, the Kotteri Hakata tasted rather bland. The sous vide egg was pretty good. But I'd have to give it to Shoryu for having the best broth compared to Bone Daddies and Kanada-Ya. The broth was spicy, thick, and flavorful. Same goes for the noodles, the best compared to Bone Daddies and Kanada-Ya. I still much prefer thick ramen noodles though. It seems to me that thick ramen noodles are nonexistent in London. Overall great service and tasty ramen. A must try!

WZFkNjGpVwLMMTa4xYw-ug.text: Excellent ramen. If you are looking for a bit of flavor in London, this is the place. The service is slow, though. Also, beware that there are ABSOLUTELY no substitutions. We could not even get a plate of sliced plain cucumbers (cucumber salad was on the menu). That was fairly ridiculous.

pm_UUGnHfxlj97u5GCijjA.text: I went back on got over my ramen envy from last time and got a shoryu ramen. I will die a happy girl. The egg wasn't as good as last time, but I'm not sure if that whole raw food thing scared the shit out of London eateries. But egg aside, we also ordered some cocktails, initially ordered a lemongrass one, but they made the wrong one and gave me a shochu sours. But everything has a bright side. SHOCHU SOURS FOR LYF. Yes. It was that good.

B-xESD-1l7A3BNeSR_1QrA.text: Shoryu was a top place to go on a chilly summer night. The ramen was pretty good. The noodles seemed a bit undercooked and the broth was so-so, but the egg was one of the best things I've ever tasted. Would come back next time I'm in London.

_ZygzU9Rnu8DRkeUaBndow.text: "Irasshaimase!". Immediately as you enter, you're greeted with a boisterous traditional Japanese welcome. It pretty much sets the tone that you're in for something authentic. Its run by the same people as the Japan Centre across the road. If the Japanese shop there, they'll probably be eating here, so you won't be disappointed.We ordered the Shoryu Tonkotsu and the Piri Piri Tonkotsu (which had just the right spicy kick). Both had pickled white ginger in it ...great for sushi, but too over-powering for soup noodles. It was shoved out the bowl and piled high on the complementary pickled red cabbage starter dish. We accompanied our meal with a side order of soft shell crab instead of the more traditional gyoza.On our waiter's recommendation, we finished the meal with the sponge cake (not on the menu). It was light and filled with fresh cream, and topped off with a macha sprinkling.Overall, a great eating experience for pre-movies or pre-theatre dining. I'd give it 5-stars, but that's reserved for Daikokuya in LA's Japan Town.yelp.co.uk/biz/daikokuya…

sFPbuhOVk5kGFQ6qjOVV6A.text: We didn't even try the food but the service was horrible. We walked in and it was packed. I stood in front of the door and I probably eyed every waitstaff there and didn't get an acknowledgment.  I didn't get asked for how many until a min later. The wait was about 10mins which was fine... I see it was busy. Then another table of 4 came in and they knew one of the workers there... And the guy started to look for a table for them. In short we were overlooked and our table was given to someone else. We weren't too happy about that, so we left. Doesn't matter who your customer know or not know you shouldn't be seating someone ahead of customers who came first when there is a table for them.

YHelbB4NZHnkbml8m7gv9g.text: One of the best ramens I've tasted outside of Japan. Great selections and the broth is divine. Very friendly, quick staff. There are sharing tables so if you come alone or even with just a few friends, you may be sharing a big table. I went by myself and sat next to an interesting group. I haven't tried the sushi here, but when the ramen is so good, you don't really need not. Price is pretty decent.

YbugfJcvr1A8M8vu01HSzw.text: Best ramen I've had in London. It gets busy though, so be prepared to queue. The steam buns are ok, but not the best I've had. My friend was disappointed they took off the salmon buns from the menu. She loved them.

S9aoESSIWqO_JyTEkwKJgQ.text: Stopped here for lunch because I was craving a bowl of ramen. I ordered the Origin Tonkotsu (£10). I had my noodles cooked normally and the ramen came topped with pork belly, mushroom and green onion. That was actually perfect because I wouldn't eat the egg anyway. The noodles here are the thinner kind, not the chewy thick ones (I prefer the thicker noodles). The bowl was kind of small. Normally, when I eat ramen, I get a bigger bowl with more soup. The soup was good, but nothing mind-blowing, especially when they advertised their soup to be 12 hour soup.The service was quick and efficient. I really liked how if you asked for tap water, they gave you a whole bottle, even though I was only 1 person.  Overall, the ramen was good. I don't have a lot of experience eating ramen in London, but I do have a ton of experience eating ramen in SF and this was ok compared to the kinds I've had in SF.

m1nW5TGe69VYtNjP0di3HA.text: Went to London on holiday came here, and now I'm depressed that I'm back home in Cardiff instead of being able to eat here every day.Honestly - if I lived in London and could afford to do so, I would eat here EVERY DAY. NO. JOKE. I'm STILL thinking about those perfectly seasoned eggs. No wonder they're on the Michelin recommended list two years in a row!~ Atmosphere:Cute atmosphere - nothing fancy. The wall has a great description of the parts of ramen, if you're new to this amazing dish you can read up on it! Even though I'm a ramen fanatic, I still learners a bit about the ramen styles of different regions in Japan.~ Customer Service:Really lovely. The waitress who served us was very sweet and friendly, and our food came out at a decent time (not alarmingly quick like they do in Japan, but still at a relatively decent time). They also provide fresh garlic you can crush right into your ramen if you're a garlic fanatic like me.~ Food:This where the 5 stars comes from. Everything else could be literally GARBAGE and I would still give this place 5 stars. We ordered Pork Belly Buns to start off with and they were fantastic. I'll be honest - I've had better baos elsewhere so next time I come I'll probably skip on the baos and go straight to the ramen just to get a better taste value for money.I ordered the Dracula Ramen (garlic tonkotsu ramen) and it was out of this world. You can order extra toppings so I opted for an extra seasoned egg. After I finished my first plate of eggs I wish I had no shame and order an extra plate. You're also allowed to ask for extra noodles or meat - all at a price of course but I'm definitely glad they had that option available.Choose the firmness of your noodles and you're ready to go - the result? The most AMAZING ramen. The depth of flavour of my ramen was immense and you can definitely bet that I slurped up all the remaining broth after I was done. If you're a ramen snob and here to compare Shoryu to the other ramen powerhouses of the world, I would say that the broth is what sets this place apart. The char siu was forgettable, but the broth and eggs were UNFORGETTABLE. I'll be thinking about this ramen for years to come.---Do yourself a favour and get to Shoryu Ramen. Probably the best in London.

Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Dracula ramen

W55NQ0SbCVX3cGD7XutIzQ.text: Hey man this joint got no flavor. I wish I can ask the chef for a refund. I should've stopped by tesco express to add some spices and real ingredients. Please save your money and go elsewhere.

Yx9WhYsFpMI53YdGWVE-WQ.text: Clean contemporary restaurant.  They announce each groups arrival with a beat of a mini Taiko drum.  I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen made with a 12 hour Pork Bone stock.  The bowl of Ramen was served with Nitamago - soft boiled egg well executed, Kikurage - wood eared fungus adding a good crunch, Nori - seaweed - adding crunch and umami flavor, generous amount of fried Shallots, a bit of spring Onions, a dollop of red ginger with a sprinkling of Sesame Seeds.The Pork Bone Broth had the requisite umami flavor, without being too salty.  The Ramen Noodle were excellent- the Noodles were al dente and the Noodles captured the flavor of the broth well.The best part of the bowl was the BBQ Pork, thin sliced, delicious Perhaps a more generous portion would make the experience more enjoyableBottom line - This is a Ramen I could eat several times a week.  It was delicious, not overly salty, has a sophisticated home made quality to it.

Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian Ramen
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Seafood Kim-chee Ramen

1ZskS0AjU-e4Wto7y4Y04w.text: Inaccurate advertising. No gluten free options whatsoever. Not sure why that's posted or why this keeps coming up as the number one spot for gluten free Noodles. Will keep on looking....

F3DPrAoTtTeE1YPcG_p_fQ.text: Service is pretty poor.Went with a few of my colleagues and we all ordered the Ramen and some drinks.  It actually took about 15-20 minutes for us to get any type of drinks and we had to remind the waiter about our drinks.  After we had the sake and it helped a little bit more.Ramen:No taste, no flavor.  BLAND.  Noodles were good.  That's it.

uIYV2zgadIVUPIuM2fGXsQ.text: I really enjoyed the ramen here! I came here a broken & hungover person and emerged a new flower. I had the signature shoryu ganso tonkotsu and the person I was with had the kotteri hakata tonkotsu and both were really really good... just nothing *mindblowing*. We did also get the two most plain ramen bowls though. The service was also outstanding (we wanted to get in, eat, get out and they were super fast/accommodating).Overall I will definitely return here and try their other menu items!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. We got the original and kotteri hakata tonkotsu - both very good!
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. We got the original and kotteri hakata tonkotsu - both very good!

U_Clq0wkH9HYj3ECluPqxQ.text: This is one of the best places I've ever eaten! Too much to write, I had the soy based ramen, hard noodles. It was absolutely delicious. Go there you will love the food and atmosphere. In the heart of Carnaby Street. This place is really special.

NinLVOgRGTw5i5JqReHafQ.text: Such tasty food! Was in the mood for ramen and hoped they'd have a vegetarian option. I don't always love tofu in ramen but the way they made it was superb - not too soft or bland. Also loved the broccoli inclusion. Servers were very responsive while not overbearing. Would definitely recommend it!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

a9s1waMl3SfBxrMMybxzHw.text: Nice ramen joint in London. They offer the typical tonkatsu as well as some interesting varieties like seafood kimchi, white vegetarian and curry. I went for the double tonkatsu broth and had a side of the black sesame tofu as a starter. The tofu was inter sting and a very instagrammable dish but not a must order. Tasted like a black sesame jello as it needed a little more sauce/wetness to it. The ramen itself was very solid. Large portion and tons of noodles. Noodles are hard and perhaps the best I've ever had. The fact that you can pick your thickness is awesome to me and really gives each ramen dish it's own rather than churned out in a factory. Chasu was thick but I wouldn't necessarily call it pork belly as mine had virtually no fat. Broth was thick and meaty, but lacked spice. Even with the piri piri side sauce I was still hoping for more. The ramen did not disappoint and it's no surprise they've expanded throughout the city. Biggest complaint was that they charged for still water when all I want d was tap. An upsell like that hurts and seems very seedy. But food wise, one of the better ramens I've had.

X0Elfz4-KH3OVc2OkM7IJA.text: Service is horrible!!! Yelp said they close at midnight but when we walked in at 10:45 they said they close in 15 minutes and we can only order off the ramen menu but no sides... they seated 4 other parties besides us and gave everyone else a menu but my boyfriend and I literally had to wave down a server to get a menu. The ramen came out fast which is good and it was delicious.However when the check came they had the audacity to add service charge to the check without my consent. Coming from America I know to tip!! The service charge was a huge turn off not to forget to mention illegal!!!!

yL2fAYqElcwJlC3Sz87cBA.text: This was not only so flavourful but coupled with great service! The noodles were perfectly cooked and the broth was so packed with flavour. I had the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu, the signature ramen and definitely promises. This was paired well with their saki flight. The place was packed and yet we still didnt have to wait long for our orders. Our server was able to make sure we enjoyed our meal!

5wL7E6NCO_v0_DjC8M-dqg.text: From the States and thought this place compares. Could use more salt for my taste. Had the Kottari and enjoyed. The Tempura Shrimp was good but bland. Again, needing a bit of salt.

51l6kVnJAmBHoRtB15pD0w.text: We had spent four hours at Houses of Parliament already, so by the time we were done at 2:30 pm, we were hangry. We found Shoryu Ramen via Yelp and immediately looked for the closest red double decker bus to take us there. Even though ramen is not the first thing you think of in terms of British cuisine, we were happily surprised to find the food worthy in the name of Japanese ramen. BF found it better than some of the ramen places in Los Angeles, and that's saying something! We ordered two bowls of the tonkotsu ramen (which includes char siu barbecue pork belly, nitamago egg, mushrooms, spring onion, sesame, ginger, and nori seaweed) and the recommended shoryu buns (2 for £7.50). We loved the ramen more than the buns and a bowl of ramen will do more than enough to keep you full. Sit by the window for people watching!

-0H6ipr1wWoQjC2VEB5JLg.text: Very good.  After a long day of touring and a long week of pub food, Shoryu was a great relief.  Funny enough i never had ramen before coming to the UK and it made me a fan.Service was good, it was a busy day for them and they still knocked it out of the park with us.  Next time in London i'll be back!

9N3Zwvkv8_ciYS3CxOwO5w.text: 2nd time ar Shoryu but 1st time at the Regent Street branch and its still in my top 3 ramen place in London!!!!This time I had the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu and still an amazing broth really meatier as advertised Plus the happy hour on all cocktail is worth it had the new seasonal wake me up in Tokyo

Z4dia2izmNEoyjXO9yfAAw.text: 1. Service - our waiter was awesome. Funny guy, and deserves a tip! He recommended what beer to get, and gave us a little run through of what to eat as well. There, you wait to be seated, order at the table, and pay at your table.2. Price - Prices may vary depending on what you order. But regarding on Ramen dishes only, it can be from 11 to 15 pounds. 3. Ambiance - Awesome decoration. Looks fitting and petit.4. Food - My wife and I both had the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu. This is their signature ramen noodle soup. We thought it was flavorful and very filling. It is prepared in Pork broth, Char Siu BBQ Pork, Nitamago Egg, Kikurage Mushrooms, Spring Onion, Sesame, Ginger, Nori Seaweed, and fried shallots. 5. Cleanliness - Food and tables were clean, but toilet didn't flush so nicely that night I was there.

ii_tHn_rzuATCCoOD1z7kA.text: Ramen is not bad but side dishes are bad! Chicken karaage is made of white meat, very dry. Why not try red meat? Seaweed salad has a whole bunch of other things in it. Can you just serve a simple seaweed salad? And no wasabi in it please.

vO6YdLWpNxJKW7bM2L4JRQ.text: One of my favorite ramen in London.Delicious ramen with good serviceTheir salad is great!Fair priced

1DXco0R8lPxkXqpA8gvfrA.text: Got our fill of ramen. The tonkatsu was flavorful and the ramen itself firm yet springy as i like my ramen. Order the miso with karage chicken ramen and slurp every drop of the soup. The chicken crispy yet moist.. very yummy. Disappointed we didn't try the signature bun.. another trip for sure. Seating was fast and easy for lunch.. will be back

v0pwxRguhgmd6PwSFuF1Dw.text: This is a solid 3 stars, if you only order the ramen. The buns were a huge disappointment, lovely soft and fluffy, ruined by iceberg lettuce, piece of cucumber and pretty rank Mayo. Not worth queuing for, pricey, but I can forgive a little of that given it is in tourist central. Broth is made centrally and shipped in, if that matters to you. I feel kind of bad about the two stars, but don't big up the buns and leave me feeling like I've been conned out of seven and a half quid ! Will I be back, probably not.

wwsXUV3pFXOxdG_drqvLfA.text: Went today to take advantage of their soft launch special where ramen is all 50% off. The place was packed!! I've never seen so many Japanese people in one place in London :PI had the spicy miso ramen which was awesome. Broth and noodles were legit. Loved it and you can't beat the price at 4 quid for the special price. Service was fast and friendly.  Soft launch special prices are until Nov 24.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Spicy Miso Ramen

9FLhX8WbBtE36iS9EC66aQ.text: Really solid ramen chain. Go for the Dracula garlic flavor or something more than just the plain option. We tried the third "hardest" noodle type and it was good, nothing too crazy. I'd try the hardest one next time. The noodles are thin and not too starchy, so the consistency worked well. The garlic broth was intense in a great way. I do wish they included corn as a topping. My husband ordered a "frozen beer" which was a fun gimmick. The place should write down orders though because they initially brought us the entirely wrong flavor for one of our bowls and had to go remake it. Then they just never delivered the appetizer we ordered. Kinda amateur service issues.

ADbdrhfe-3Tm9R55Od7-ag.text: Authentic and Nice atmosphere. Friendly service :)Had the signature dish ( tonkotsu ramen) and hirata bun as side. Great value, and large portions!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

z0YdwmII1qVc6VmkEyziTg.text: This place is amazing.  Original and vegetarian were both delicious.  I've been dreaming about the broth and the noodles ever since.  Very warming on a cold winter night.

d_TpDfOvLh6SCVnst5ErKA.text: To be honest, one of the best meals we had in London. Despite the poor service (bad attitude) the food was very good. The soup was thick and the noodles was perfect too. Great reman!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. The spicy one

h6AQxx1-Hb23PWjakN3NEQ.text: Best ramen I have ever had! I ordered the kimchi seafood ramen ! Spicy with fresh squid, scallops and  prawns!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Dumplings
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Kimchi seafood

1N3EMiK7hTK3FQyNZ5oNBQ.text: Tried the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and though it was alright. The broth has flavor, but felt like it was watery. I am comparing it to the ramen I had in California which was pretty flavorful. The ramen noodle itself wasn't anything to right about.However, I also tried their Shoryu buns and I would recommend it to anyone who goes there. The meat is pretty tender and flavorful. Having only been there once, I would give this place another try. Maybe the chef was having a bad day.

T8_Qh9yW0vMx-33hcQbSDA.text: Winter ramen.  Soup is good, prices anywhere from 10 to 20 pounds. Not so busy, so service alright.  No cockroaches on my food.  I'm not crazy about ramen but enjoy them from time to time.

c7W_X0mSpq-B6dpmuh1Gtg.text: Overall a good meal.  But the whitebait just wasn't good.The wagyu buns were large and fluffy compared to others, but were filled with tasty beef and melted in your mouth.  The Piri piri Tonkotsu ramen was good.  Lots of flavor with a beautiful egg and a nice kick.  The gyoza was nicely done with a crunchy lace in the bottom of the skillet.The whitebait was fishy though.  Didn't taste very fresh.  Didn't finish these.

j-k_yJo0UR_xjUZqcGth1Q.text: Pretty good ramen by London standards, can be a little salty, but if you're in the area, is always a good choice for a bite of Japanese. Take note that queues can be long, so be prepared for a wait. I tried the black garlic ramen, which was unique and left me warm and happy. The space can be a little cramped due to the huge number of people they have, so the point is - eat fast and get the hell out of there, and reflect on how tasty it was after you leave. Worth a try for sure.

e6uFmbdUuvv3W5tVHm4HBA.text: Best ramen I've had!! Visiting from the US and I will have serious cravings for this place later. Cute little restaurant and friendly staff. The broth they use is seriously amazing! I got the standard ramen bowl they had with the fried shallots, no nori (just cause I'm not a fan of seaweed), and it was seriously so delicious! Would definitely recommend!

PCoI8qvOSk1xPQpJ3moxiA.text: If you like spicy food, don't listen to the waitress warnings. Specialty cocktails were good but the ramen stole the show

U8SuUhFTgABiS1zhWks_7Q.text: I enjoyed my Shoryu Tonkatsu ramen but personally I prefer the Bone Daddie Tonkatsu ramen more. I found the ramen here to be very good, with generous serving portion, more toppings and equally satisfying, however, I still pick BD tonkatsu over it. My reasoning behind it is that I felt that the broths (both pork and chicken) there were much tastier and with more intense flavour.As for the service here, my experience with Shoryu was as good as our service in BD. I had no complaints. Overall, Shoryu was good but my taste buds seek the BD flavour.

sVIr7CGBiWmwqhGWIgjmXw.text: This ramen is clearly geared towards the western palate.  If you're looking for authentic Japanese ramen, this isn't really it.  It is still good though.  We did have an unfortunate thing happen when we went; my friend's phone was stolen while we were eating there.  Keep an eye on your things while you're there!

y2dvhWhW7b3Fy96u2U9fdQ.text: Very good ramen place. We had the spicy ramen (#4) and normal (#1). Topped off with frozen Kirin (draft beer topped with frozen foam made from beer -- so it keeps it colder longer without diluting the beer when it melts). I added fresh pressed garlic (sorry to my darling wife). Although the ramen was very tasty, the presentation isn't to be overlooked. From the bowl and wooden ladle to the layout of the ingredients on top (half an egg, thin slices of pork, chopped onions, etc). Perfect after freezing our fingers and toes off for an hour+ watching the changing of the guards at Buckingham Palace.

MeCjKuppj3TFF9jn7JYv3Q.text: This place has the best buns I've ever tasted and Monday 2-4-1 is a steal. The ramen is top too. If you're in town you just visit

oDDr_mN3ryOO0LQWBfUF6A.text: The ramen was wonderful. Ordered a signature ramen. Besides the ramen, I ordered a pork bun too. However, it came out a little disappointing, as the bun is cut into halves instead of folded, like how it was supposed to be. There was also some mayonnaise used in the pork bun, which to me, was a bad idea to a cuisine like this. When it was served, the bun was a little cold, indicating that it was not freshly steamed. On the other hand, the broth to the ramen was just nice! Perfect! And I like how we get to choose the tenderness of the noodle. Overall, the ramen is good, and the ambience is perfect since the server tries to use Japanese but I would avoid the pork bun.

z0SBc7PbfhdeiAoRvTF0zg.text: This is just a review of the veggie ramen - I've heard excellent things about the non-veg but haven't tried it.The veggie ramen is wholesome and satisfying - exactly what you want on a cold day. It's a little bit bland, which is why I recommend getting it with the chilli sauce, but with that addition it's delicious.

QvD5kPpJfe-j6y1iTmmnBw.text: A comedy of bad service. Don't buy the wine. They served probably the worst expensive Chablis I have ever had. They also failed to have almost any of the gluten free items on the menu. Finally they did not deliver one main. It was my main and I can't review the food because after a long wait I didn't eat. Dead loss.

I2z74ofQ8H8nv5c56Ak83g.text: The best ramen I've ever had!The cleanest Ramen restaurant I've yet seenThe friendliest staff you can imagineThe (1 of) best finds we stumbled upon in Soho LondonWe both had the special tonkatzu broth with marinated ground pork. And the pork belly bun.. Both Soooo good!!Highly recommend this place from this girl that's been to many many ramen places from the west to the east.. and some places in between.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

QnRAggOwYhF19Xi4T_64tg.text: There wasn't many ramen restaurants in the area when we were visiting but we gave this one a shot and it did not disappoint! The staff was friendly and the space was pretty standard. The ramen was super tasty and had a perfect broth. I loved how you can order the tenderness of your noodle!Sushi apps were pretty good too!

L147EUBlEugo7g42BRyLUg.text: Good food, terrible service.A week ago we went to another Shoryu location (Carnaby street) and after a short wait in line we were promptly seated and served impressively quickly.At the New Oxford location today, we arrived and were seated without a wait but then we waited over 25 minutes to have a server show up and take even our drink order. This was despite asking various servers multiple times to place an order and always being deferred. The place was almost full but not really busy so the poor service was pretty inexcusable.After eating (tasty food), our bill had major issues twice (once it was just unrelated; the second time it had a number of extra items). Finally, a manager had to help correct the bill. We had to ask twice for the service charge to be removed.

oq2G4-kJZh-moJT3VERRLA.text: Oh I just love the fact that it is possible to walk in to a place and almost feel like I stepped into a place in Japan. Service is nice and the food is good. You are looking at a repeat costumer here.

nPHENnwWj3MNftHHe0-tqQ.text: Heatwave in London. Warmest summer ever and what better than a super hot face melting bowl of Ramen!  Gambate! Itadakimaaaas!I peeked over the door noren and I see this place is packed already. I guess I wasn't the only one mad in the brain to eat hot ramen on a hot day. Anyhoo.. I held up 4 fingers and the hostess seemed to know I meant .. table for 4.  So she led me to the tiniest of tables, crammed next to 2 of the tiniest of tables, and with a quick Hai Dozo.. I was left there.  But,... but.... I cannot possible traverse the tiny space between the tables to get my seat on the inside.  I mean.. people were already eating , and their bowls of ramen was perched on their tables, and I would most def, either knock their table over... or even worst.. go past the tables sideways and put my butt right over their table.. So I gave the hostess a helpless look.. ehh...sumimasen... but she looks away.  Fine.. be like that.. so I proceed to wedge myself between table and takes seat.. So uncool. Tho my wife rolled her eyes at me.  I needed ramen, I needed something to restore my center.  The walking and sightseeing and meal decisions while visiting London has been exhausting.  I needed ramen to get back to basic.  We got us, Dracula Ramen, Regular Tonkotsu, I think there was Spicy Miso too.  tldr;- None was spectacular. It wasn't bad.  But it lacked an identity.  The noodles was text book, the broth standard, the chashu pedestrian, the toppings bleh.  In a sea of ramen.. Shoryu ramen did not stand out one bit.  Service was so-so.  I don't expect it at a Ramen-ya anyway.  So I was fine with bare minimum.  I don't know if there is better Ramen in London.  This isn't bad, but I would search harder the next time for something better.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

bPVEldRLq-IpnPt86qEr-Q.text: After a cold day walking around London, the idea of a hot bowl of noodles sounded great. There was a bit of a line to get in so that was a good sign. Turns out this is a chain. To some, that's off putting or inauthentic. But when done in a respectful way - and tasty way, who cares? When you finally get called for saying they hit a drum and yell something that's supposed to be in Japanese. Cute and sets the Japanese motif. I like that you are able to request noodle doneness for the ramen. In general, I found the ramen (we tried two different ones) to be a little bland but otherwise really good. It had the nice soft boiled egg (but with a slightly reddish yolk). The BBQ pork bao was pretty delicious with a substantial piece of meat. The Soho platter was a pretty posh sampler of food including sashimi, tempura, and Kara age chicken for two. They even had a near-frozen Asahi beer that really hit the spot against the fatty broth of the ramen. We skipped the cocktails but they looked really delicious.We skipped dessert but overall, it was a pretty good meal and surprisingly inexpensive vs. expectations. Would definitely recommend this place for ramen cravings!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

wtrTpFD9rN8A01z_7y4Clg.text: Tasty ramen with the beautiful chew to the freshly made ramen.  Stumbled upon this place since we couldn't find the place we were looking for but, we love finding new gems.  Food was really good, broth was very tasty.  The calpico mojito was very refreshing since it was blistering hot in London.  The chicken karage bun was good but I loved the tonkotsu ramen.  I would have had another bowl of just the broth.  Love the find and will be back the next time I'm in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Hot takoyaki advertisement- couldn't eat anymore but will come back to try it!!!
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Mojito Loves Calpico !- this was really good and refreshing
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Still water in pretty bottle

Zs-EQLa7mKx0ftoDziCPVg.text: It was our last night in London....and knowing that we had a long night ahead of reluctantly packing to head back in Atlanta....Hubby and I opted to stop by here for a simple warm dinner, and romantic walk under the Christmas lights on Regent street. Shoryu came highly recommended by friends and yelpers. It was a cold night so a warm bowl of ramen seemed like a perfect option. We hopped in a uber and arrived with no reservations made prior. Luckily, it was not too busy despite being a Friday night. We were able to find cozy two seats at the front right corner so we could people watch (very fun on a Friday night). I love the detail of purse hooks under the table. They offer specials such as seasonal set menu, Bun Monday, and Happy Sake hour. Shoryu Ramen started in Nov. 2012 and recommend in the Michelin Guide since 2014 (you still see the sticker at the entrance). They specialize in Hakata Tonkotsu ramen (aka, rich-thick- white pork broth with straight ramen noodles). Ricky and I both ordered the same Shoryu tonkatsu ramen ....and the broth was amazing! You can tell it has been cooking for many hours with great quality ingredients. And do not forget about the noodles made from fresh Shoryu flour! Fresh, bouncy, and chewy. You can request different textures to your liking. The ramen comes with the traditional toppings of a soft boiled egg, pork, and veggies,and nori. All the toppings were excellent as well.....but I am a BIG soup and noodles person so those are the items that grabbed by attention the most. The gyoza is supposed to be really good here but unfortunately no one told me -_-. I didn't find this out till after I left the restaurant. The uber driver asked me if I got the dumplings on the ride back to the hotel. We got the takoyaki instead which was so-so. Another popular item is the HIrata Bun. Hubby got the wagyu beef filled bun. They names it the Shoryu bun to bring prosperity to you when you eat it :) Very cute. This location also has quiet an extensive alcohol selection. Def check this out. There was a reason everyone inside was drinking lol. Highly recommend. Great place for ramen.

iYXEiDi0joI3VK51YgEOTw.text: Been here twice now and each time was delicious! I got the spicy vegetarian both times and it was amazing, hot and well seasoned each time! Service was also very fast and attentive!

qSoi8aHCIuVuzMO0EwwXSQ.text: Who would have thought that there would have been such an awesome ramen place in London? Shoryu Ramen definitely surpassed my expectations.The broth was flavorful, and the noodles cooked to perfection. Service was great for us, as we came before the rush, as they quickly took our orders and brought out the food in a timely manner. The restaurant is a bit small, but it is nice and cozy. I would try to get here before or after it gets really busy.

kVAXxgpk7BQs_d_5PX9YVg.text: Loved this place so much my first time in London I made my group come back on my next visit. The ramen is tasty and authentic and leaves me satisfied every time.We came in Monday which turned out to be Bun Monday (buy one get one free)! We came in around 2 pm and we're seated right away. Keep in mind the later it gets the more crowded because my first time was a 45 minute wait in the evening.

CihlMdwCsIZFW6X9q2tixw.text: Went for early dinner,  and got four bowls of ramen. All were good. The Curry Ramen was very spicy. My son, who can handle almost anything, could not eat the whole bowl. Mine was good, too, but needed a little soy sauce to heighten the flavor. Drinks were a little high.

ReU7S3hIenrO5Yli4rT8TA.text: Very busy! Cozy and fast serviceFood was delicious (big portions which is a plus!) Was charged a 2,5% service fee (not sure if this is normal but as a tourist I wasn't aware- obviously not a problem but just a heads up) Their ramen is super flavourful, probably the best I've had. Really authentic flavours and ingredients used! Must try their bao buns and green curry ramen! Reading a few reviewers- their service review might be a bit wishy washy, I think it does depend on if they are really busy or not, as well as the staff working at the time

VptIJx-gm2gvNQugugKvtw.text: I had such horrible service here which is why I am only giving it 3 stars although the food was a strong 4. Service: Took several minutes to get our order taken. Then when we were ready to pay, there was a staff member talking to another staff member on her break at the table next to us. Completely ignored us although we tried getting her attention. Finally got the attention of our waitress (the only one serving the whole place), to ask a question about a discount we had. She gave us an explanation then walked away for another several minutes when we had to flag her down for the bill. Again, staff seated to our left acted oblivious. I don't know how they run a business here.Food: Very tasty, full of flavour and good portion size. I enjoyed my Dracula tonkatsu ramen. It was hearty and delicious. Verdict: I would return to another place gladly, given this poor service doesn't extend to all their locations. Clearly they have good food, they just need to work on hiring good people.

6jqNWqGnPNM21-5Qzxtpxw.text: There were two main reasons for dining here: it had been recommended by the Michelin guide and, if you're a fellow Street Fighter fan, then you'll understand the other reason why. Along with our respective bowls of ramen (one Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu, one Dracula Tonkotsu), we also ordered a couple of the Shoryu buns.Personally I wasn't a huge fan of the buns as they actually had quite a bit of mayo on them. They were still tasty but I would probably pass on them on any subsequent visit.The ramen was quite good and you have the choice of how you would like your noodles prepared. The broth of the Hakata Tonkotsu was flavorful, savory, and rich. The double nitamago egg was eggsellent. The Dracula Tonkotsu is filled with tasty garlic bits and flavour but may require an after-meal mint. 3.5 stars overall.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

VT0CDZRrt6VrF0SB0GfO4A.text: Was visiting London with my fiance, and after a long day of walking, we were craving a carb-heavy meal like ramen. We stopped by shoryu, which was decently busy on a weekday late afternoon. We were asked to wait outside for a few minutes as they were cleaning the tables. I got the dracula tonkotsu and my fiance ordered the tonkotsu with the more intense/ thicker broth. We both enjoyed our meal - you can order the noodles cooked to your preferred doneness (standard, firm, etc.) and the egg that came with the noodles was cooked perfectly. My soup base was a little too garlicky for my tastes, but that was my fault since the description clearly detailed that it was for garlic lovers. My fiance said this was probably one of the better ramen places he's eaten at (and we've been to plenty in Chicago and NY)The meal was a little pricey for what it was, but we were in the heart of London so I expect part of it was due to location so can't really complain there.

5bMDE2UhO2o0klUIzCJWfQ.text: Best Ramen ever!!Curiously, when taken apart the individual ingredients are really good, but not my favorite.  I prefer thicker noodles, the perfect egg and more Kimchee.  However, it is this combination that adds to perfection.I had the Spicy Seafood Tonkotsu.  I am delighted by these scallops that have a firm texture and full-flavor (being used to farm-raised ones).  The Ramen is not spicy and you can add chili oil and grind fresh sesame seed to taste.My companions have the pork version that they love.  With a bit extra, you can have a Shoryu bun and a boozy cocktail with your meal.Great if you love Ramen!

y0fjZ5cUBd0Q_6oxfaQ41A.text: I've never had ramen before but boy was I missing out. This place was absolutely delicious, very flavourful and surprisingly affordable. Service was amazing and you could tell the staff was really passionate about their food. Will definitely come back again

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

xMKjWHi8-4UYVW6pn3jXqw.text: oVery busy and famous ramen restaurant, still have to wait after 10:00 in the night.. ordered the signature ramen and soft shell crab, it was not bad, but little bit disappointed because the taste not as good as o thought

UuSqfH-yclEOY0Qg2o9nfQ.text: Super rich broth...very tasty. I have actually never had someone ask me how I like my noodles cooked...that was a nice touch. I've had really good ramen and this place is up there in the ranks of the best. The service was good, attentive, friendly. Skip the frozen beer slushy...it just makes it take longer to get to your actual beer. Definitely a must taste if you're in the area and hungry or jetlagged or hung over. It's a comforting bowl of brothy meat love to cradle your heart!

lri3DaP83X9D9PaKeOGA7Q.text: The Donkatsu ramen was very good.  Rich and brothy.  Much better than what I tasted in Paris.  However, not as good as in SF or Japan but well worth the 1.5 miles walk from my hotel.  Also had the tempura and sesame tofu.  The tempura was good but not too much batter.  Not as crunchy as it could have been.  The black sesame toy was new and good.  I would definitely come back!

hPU8kxNFiYM0xK1PuPyw-g.text: The pork belly buns were flavourfull and yummy; the gyoza had a fresh pork filling that reminded me of homemade (although the skins were not).  I had the original ramen which was a big bowl of miso pork broth with two fatty slices of pork, some seaweed and scallions.  This was good although I did have food envy for my friend's signature ramen (there was half an egg!)  One drawback on the broth was that it was quite greasy.  Defat the broth!  It's not hard to do and really makes for a better, non-greasy experience.  It's not fun having to wipe your lips because it feels like you've put on too much lip balm.While I liked Shoryu and would go back, the main drawback is the seating.  I think they are trying to provide an authentic, Tokyo experience by making the tables as crowded together as possible.  It is not a place to have any sort of intimate conversation with anyone because you are literally right up against the person sitting next to you.  I get turning tables but Shoryu borders on the ridiculous.  No wonder there were so many solo diners.  You wouldn't want to go here for a friendly chat or first date!

swzIpGKQF6nS1BPLeFeHzA.text: I've been to a lot of ramen places in the US (mostly in California), but Shoryu Ramen in London is hands down the best I've had. We were in town for less than a week, and naturally we wanted to try out as many restaurants as possible, but we ended up eating here twice because it was so good.The wait was quite long for dinner, but we were able to be seated immediately for lunch. It's a small, packed space and you will most likely be seated at a table connected to another party.I got the curry ramen both times. It was unique, flavorful, and the perfect portion. The only suggestion I have is to put the karaage chicken on the side, so as not to have them turn soggy.  Additionally, the lychee strawberry drink was amazing, but maybe not worth £6.

nSDIMierLC0qznQZjWDwVA.text: very nice. we got two spicy vegans and one tonkatsu. the aesthetic and atmosphere itself is very cozy. service is prompt and answer all and any questions you have. food is delicous and huge-as ramen always is. and it's open late!

i34oWkpDW1gu3r9ECEr3yQ.text: After going to Japan recently, my husband and I are now massive ramen snobs.  We've been to Shoryu in Soho before and loved it, so we gave this one a try on a Sunday night (no booking) to see if it was as good as we remembered.It's a packed and busy place, with no room to wait inside, but it was only about 10 minutes before we made it in the door with my parents and grandmother.  I had the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu - their signature ramen with meatier broth and two eggs, as well as barbecued pork belly, mushrooms, spring onion, sesame, ginger, and seaweed.  Drool.  You can choose how firm you want the noodles too (firm all the way!) and we passed around a few sides of lovely Chicken Karaage - Japanese fried chicken.  It was, as expected, lush, although not the completely glorious closed-eyes experience I remembered from the other Shoryu (I think Japan has ruined me forever).  The broth is just lacking that particular je ne sais quoi that we ate in Asia, but everything else about the dish - noodles, pork, accoutrements, were lovely and craveable.  The fried chicken was very good, with a more delicate batter than you usually get with fried chicken, no bones, and a very hot temperature so watch your tongue!A very affordable and delicious place to go for dinner.  Not a bad substitute if you can't make it to Tokyo!

9er2R7IqNuDB-IEYlAZkmw.text: I've now had the chance to return to Shoryu to try more of their menu. In fact, their ever burgeoning menu. I'm impressed quickly they've added dishes to their menu, both in the ramen and the starter/side dishes categoriesThey've also tweaked service slightly. You still get the cheerful Japanese greeting but they've done away with the drum they hit with each new customerThey've expanded their ramen menu with both traditional and innovative combinations. I want to love their ramen but can only bring myself to like it. At the risk of sounding ungrateful, I think they put too much in their bowl. I like ramen because I like to taste the ramen noodles but the noodles get lost with all the other parapernalia they put into the bowlThey've also greatly expanded their starter/side dish menu. I have to give a shout out to their belly pork hirata buns. These are made up with 2 steamed buns which are quite dense but the perfect foil to the sweet soft pork which they sandwich. I had discovered these at Ippudo in New York and am so glad that I've found somewhere in London which does themIf you want a range of dishes, go to Shoryu for their range. However, if you want the best bowl ramen, I'd still recommend Bone Daddies

FRYM2BTdKag0Sbp6PiKQsg.text: Ramen and buns are okay. Service was prompt. The price is reasonable compared to london standards. They add a service charge to your bill. Come here early as the place gets packed after 6pm.

bQKbERJQeq6anKw5WNHWrA.text: Delicious and fresh of the salmon I recommend the spicy reman.My friend and I love this place. The service here is great. The waiters are friendlyWhen you pay the bill,it contain the tip ,10% of the cost.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Spicy

Ekac8QsXSuBt2ha1ojXT1Q.text: Me and some friends took advantage of the massive discounts Shoryu was offering and payed the new shop in Piccadilly a visit.   I gotta say in advance that my opinion about the place was not very positive for a good part of the evening but then built up and ended on a good note.  When we first arrived, we were left outside on a queue waiting to get in with no indication of whether it would take 10 minutes or 1 hour. Not a big deal, but doesn't get anyone any points either. When we finally got a table, we had to wait quite a while to get a menu (which only arrived after us chasing the waiter). 10 minutes later, 2 more people were squeezed in into our table - clearly a management attempt to fit in as many people as possible.  It is fair to say that there wasn't much space left in the table, but that didn't matter as far as the drinks were concerned: 3£ for the smallest orange juice I've ever seen in my life.  Those were the not so good points... but then a storm of flavor arrived and washed that all away.  The starters are really really good, specially the Hirata Buns - the pork ones are spicy but terrific. We also had Soft Shell Crab Tempura which were more than enough for 4 people.  The main Ramen dishes completely met our expectations: flavorful, big portions, good balance between the ingredients. We struggled to finish them after all those starters so it's worth building up your appetite before visiting the place! I had the Tori Kara-Age Men and was quite happy with it - only negative was the size of the fish cake portion: way too small.   We also ordered an extra cold Ramen to try it out. Unfortunately, the waiter brought us the wrong one, so not sure which one it was. Overall the service was a bit all over the place and not that well organized, but the staff was friendly and approachable. Can't really give this one a 5 but the food was good enough to stir away from a 3.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Tori Kara - Age Man

XhEIgZYio29M7I-yNOa3vw.text: 3.5 starsDecent ramen in London??? Not sure I even recognise this city anymore. I swear every place has only popped up in the year I was away. (Which is incredible!)Ramen:Any place with tonkotsu broth, I'm going to invariably compare to ippudo. The broth was good to be sure but just not as flavourful as I'd like. It lacks a certain intensity you find in other places.Noodles here are pretty nice. Again, not big on flavour but they have a wonderful texture. Definitely Shoryu's USP.Sides:Had gyozas, chicken karaage, and pork buns. All were extremely enjoyable. Pork buns are a must order. Overall:I'd give the ramen 3.5 stars objectively. In Singapore or New York, I'd say this is an average ramen place. It's a safe choice, enjoyable, but really nothing special. In London though, those same factors mean it's effectively 5 stars. If you're craving ramen, you'll be satisfied.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Pork bun
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu

Xj2GaUEO4Gn3sG0W7YadWw.text: I queued in the snow for nearly an hour... just to eat this ramen.(And gyoza and onigiri)AND IT RULED.After we finally got in, we got lucky and secured the only 2 seater table in the place. We were right against the window and had to turn our knees outward as they didn't fit under the table, and I had a fire extinguisher sticking out from the wall behind me. It's definitely a squash in here when it's full so be warned. But unlike Bone Daddies your lack of space doesn't come with uncomfortably loud music and petty portion sizes. So it's even more worth it.We ordered some drinks and a portion of gyoza. They came pretty quickly and were awesome. The gyoza skins were nicely crispy and the perfect thickness.Then our ramens arrived. I had the Charsui Tonkotsu for £10 a bowl - which is kind of expensive, but the portion is really generous and it's so good - again this beat Bone Daddies offering. There was lots of broth (GOOD) and the perfect amount of noodles and meat and lots of toppings. The broth was the perfect texture, it had that tonkotsu thickness but wasn't too fatty and greasy. My husband went for the Dracula Tonkotsu, which he loved. It was essentially the richer, garlicy-er version of the normal Tonkotsu and was a dream come true. We asked for vinegar and shichimi powder. They brought a huge metal jug of vinegar and a cute wooden container of shichimi, the waiter was quite funny about the size of the vinegar and the vinegar was really, really good. I love vinegar in my ramen so finding a place that offers it on-menu is a huge plus.When we saw the specials board we couldn't help ordering a couple of onigiri. They were meant to come with brown rice but as they were running out they asked if we'd mind one with white rice. They were so apologetic and said if we didn't like it with white rice we could have one with brown for free! But for me this was even better as I prefer white rice. They were filled with pickles and really delicious.The onigiri filled us up quite a lot and when we couldn't finish the ramen, we were so happy to find they'd bag everything up in a takeaway bag for us to take home.The service was good, with one minor slip up when a different waiter tried to deliver a second plate of dumplings to us and didn't apologise for the mistake, aside from that it was pretty perfect.I love the food here. If it wasn't for the cramped space (sorry, I know it's ramen bar style but I'm still getting used to these packed-in restaurants!) and the fact we had to queue for so long it'd be a 5 star straight away!

aM2RXNvPBu5FbgcKN3GTPQ.text: Great ramen place, though not the most authentic (pickled ginger strips, what are you doing in my ramen soup??) and a bit pricey. Close to Piccadilly Circus. Make sure to go early if you have a large party, especially for dinner because this place fills up fast.

POVSWDoI7hbFkWggPvuB1A.text: I had their signature ramen dish. It's ok but I've had better. Broth was a bit bland for my taste, noodles were decent but could be better. Pork was very good. I'd eat here again if I was in the area but wouldn't come specially for this.

fEWsY-NsD-aFl3f3fSb9kQ.text: Great value for money in London- very enjoyable food - company and service- sure there is better about but this is a great sushi - Japanese Restrauant in a nice quite location- you will enjoy it without fuss- walked in freestyle for a Restrauant and found this gem. Was very close t giving it a 4 star rating - but is just isn't there yet

mEWmucMgWTHB5o1qasWDMQ.text: I tried the Karaka TanTan Tonkotsu Ramen which were garlicky spicy noodles with minced pork on top.  My egg was a bit overcooked, I do like the yolk soft and runny.  My Tantan noodles were on the saltier side.  The only thing that annoyed me was that all the minced pork sunk to the bottom of the bowl, and I spent most of my time trying to fish it out. I think I'm gonna stick with basic Tonkotsu noodles, where I actually get slices of pork.  To share, we had the Chicken Karaage - same as last time, nicely fried!  We also ordered Gyoza, but for 5, I felt it was quite understuffed and small.  The wrapping was a bit on the hard side.  The pork filling was good, nothing wrong with that.  But I think for the value, I'll stick with just the karaage. My friend ordered the Charsiu Tonkotsu - which is pretty much your classic noodles but with extra pork.  I tasted the broth, and strangely enough, it was... on the sweeter side.  I thought it was just me, but he tasted it too and thought it was definitely sweet.  Anyway, still a nice place to go to, but I think my go-to place is Bone Daddies for now.
