AKniyIPNfJ6J06b-yvWHiA.text: So yummy. Much Umami. Goooood!Quick lunch in trafalgar square and around? planning for some ramen but you already tried sasuke (which is better!)? Definitely come here. Especially if you are alone.The place is not that big with many small tables and a counter running all over the window. No-nonsense chart, solid ramens, some buns and just a couple of other dishes. But you definitely wanna get the ramen.Take the one you prefer, I usually go for the standard one when I want to try a new place (first you show me you can cook a steak, then you can make a filetto alla rossini!), and just stare at the broth: Brown, thick, if I didn't knew it was liquid I'd have said it was a cream! Definitely something special, you can feel that it will be delicious just by looking at it! That my friends is probably the best broth I ever had in my ramen. The egg follows the same description, just absolutely amazing, cooked at the perfection, and overall a real pleasure.The only thing missing, and the reason why it stands below Sasuke in my personal RAMENED competition (Ramen Axelrod May Eat Night & Day) is regarding the thickness of the noodles, which I found a bit too thin for my personal palate. But that's just me being an annoying stickler.Just come here and enjoy the delicious broth!

6ZibP0UKfQHT7NBFzVApZQ.text: I got a very good Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu. The broth was very tasty and there was quite a lot of meat and vegetables inside.The only problem is that the standard noodles are very thin. If you prefer the bigger noodles you must tell it when you order.Every day they also have a day offer: when I went there it was 2 buns at the price of 1. Which is a pretty good offer since it means that you'll pay just 2.25£ per each.

IcchsJRzOAt3u1cbW60k0w.text: I only was told about this ramen place two weeks ago while trying out another Ramen bar ... since then I have been three time. Yes, it is that good. I like most of the broths, also some were too salty. I also tried the different sides and they are all delicious. I'm a fan. ... but I think I will stop going now, as I need to give other places a try as well.One word of warning: on the weekend we had to queue for a place, but on a normal weekday ... if you go straight after work ... you will find a spare seat.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

FGrU1hj5ZTbV9lrSeo6pSA.text: I've been to Shoryu now twice, once during their soft opening and once afterwards. This place specializes in a a different sort of white soup ramen from a particular region in Japan. Compared to places like Bone Daddies, this is more of an authentic Japanese-style ramen place (but that's not to say that authenticity=better). Service: When I went during the soft opening, they were definitely still working out the kinks. They have one waitress in particular who we've named 'waitress happy pants' because of her... rather surly demeanor. Quite frankly, I don't know if she was just having a horrible day or what, but I am very forgiving when it comes to bad service, but less so when they are snappy and eye-rolly and seem like they hate their job and everything is the customer's fault (even when it isn't). At any rate, she was actually more hilarious than frustrating, so whatever. Food: High soup to noodle content, the soup is flavorful but not quite rich enough for my personal tastes, some nice goodies in the bowl, but not quite enough of them. The ramen noodles themselves were the best thing about this bowl, really good. The first time I got the Shoryu Ramen, which was nice. The second time I had the Tokyo Ramen, which was soy sauce based broth with fish cake and bamboo. I think I prefer the Shoryu because it was one of the specialty white broths. Do order the egg, as they are well seasoned and quite nice (though it is a shame they don't come automatically with a bowl like they do at Tonkotsu and Bone Daddies). My dining partner had the yuzu ramen, which was really tasty. When I come back, I want to try to spicy miso and the yuzu ones. That said, and this is just personal preference, I found the overall dining experience and food at Bone Daddies to be more satisfying, but it is actually quite hard to compare the two as they are totally different ramen beasts. I'll certainly be back to Shoryu as well, when I want a soupier/less heavy noodle experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu Ramen

Xd8mi70nMtfzbqrN_uNF6g.text: I only had one vegetarian choice here...and I loved it! I also had the sake flight of the day and it was a great discovery. The non-Japanese staff kept yelling random-sounding phrases in Japanese. Not too sure what that means but whatever! It's a small place so be ready to wait, it's worth it.

F9ly0njedlFpaYQxZuSFFw.text: I think this was better then Bone Daddies in the soup to noodle ratio.I dug. The house classic tonkotsu was pretty damn good.Nice service. Would bring friends back here agin.

7IRlqe-p8kzlc8rzlTwbdQ.text: I recently visited a little gem I frequent on Regent Street, London named Shoryu Ramen. Since its opening in November 2012 they have been offering their Hakata Tonkotsu ramen, a recipe which was specially designed by executive chef, Kanji Furukawa. Shoryu translates to mean 'to bring good fortune'.I find Shoryu to be an understated, modest establishment, however its popularity speaks for itself. You cannot reserve a table ahead of time and frequently I spot a line that reaches way outside into the busy streets of Soho. A ringing endorsement in itself and an indication of quality before you even enter the front door!Their menu is refreshingly simple - as their name suggests, they mainly offer steaming bowls of ramen, amongst other small plates and of course, steamed buns!I HAD to try their steamed buns as this delicious creation is one of my latest favourites. For those yet to discover these beauties, a steamed bun - as the name suggests, consists of a variety of fillings, encased in a pillowy, fluffy steamed-dough bunI opted to try two different variations, the Char Sui barbecue pork belly (left) and the soy marinated chicken Karaage (right). Now I'm never short of an opinion, but I REFUSE to pick a favourite, they are both unbelievably spot-on. The pork belly was packed with flavour and smothered in charred-sweet sauce, which married well with the crunch of the salad and the softness of the bun, whilst the contrast of the crispiness of the chicken against the cloud-soft bun was to die for!You just simply have to try these, plus they offer more variations on their menu, namely; their ginger salmon Tatsutage, their tiger prawn Tempura, and their vegetarian-friendly, grilled Halloumi & Shimeji mushrooms.Quite honestly, after those two delicious helpings of steamed buns - I really couldn't imagine tackling their rich, generous serving of Ramen - I had to give myself a break! But I finally opted for their Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu - their signature 12-hour ramen, but with a richer, meatier broth. I loved this dish, it has variety, balance and is the exact antidote to a hectic day, rushing around London. This steaming bowl of warmth allows you to take a much-needed pause.Ok, I will admit that I had to take half of this serving home to enjoy, however I'd argue that after the flavours were able to muddle for even longer it made for an even more delicious serving. Don't be ashamed to take your ramen on the tube home!Shoryu Ramen isn't the least expensive establishment you can visit, but its comforting simplicity, packed with flavour keeps me coming back. A would definitely recommend this to anyone who is an Asian-food lover. Or to anyone who has yet to try their first bowl of Ramen or steamed-bun - this is a great place to start!...And a tip to any Ramen-lover on a budget - you can take a ramen, steamed-bun and a drink to go for just £12 with their go PACKAGE. I've only ever visited their Regent St. location, but why not visit their other restaurants located in Soho, Carnaby and Liverpool Street? Does anyone have a preference? Let me know!Happy Slurping!See the original blog here: laurajreeves.com/2015/05…

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

6pdixalHEg3YoC79usc9cA.text: Chose to eat an early dinner at Shoryu as it was a short walk from my hotel. Their menu seems extensive given the number of pages. I chose to start with a Pork Char Siu Bun to start. The Pork Char Siu came in a fluffy bun with sliced cucumber, lettuce and mayo. I liked it, but wish it had a couple of slices of pork. They have several versions of Tonkotsu Ramen. I chose the Piri Piri which is their spicy version. All the ramen come with the sliced pork, half a soft boiled egg, mushrooms, seaweed, roasted garlic and thin noodle egg ramen. The broth was rich and thick, but to my surprise not very spicy at all. I kind of wanted more heat, so a little disappointed. I didn't see the red pepper anywhere either. But they do have the fresh garlic in a bucket with the crusher, if you choose to want to squeeze some into your ramen, which I did. I did like their noodles as it was thin and chewy. The service was good. And they leave a whole bottle of tap water for you which I thought was convenient. For my ramen and pork bun, it was £18.45 which included what they called a "12.5 optional service charge". That's strange to me as its already in the total.  Does that mean that I could have left £16.40 and they would have been ok with it?

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. The bill for a ramen, pork bun and "optional 12.5% service charge"
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Piri Piri Ramen and Pork Bun

6VFRrFhEKEJtMNR1s7mkbg.text: Oooh shoryu ramen is another good place to stop for a bowl of noodles, although like Vicky, I liked it, but didn't LOVE it. Maybe all the other new-ish (excellent) ramen places have made it harder to impress me in London?I was really impressed by the variety of soups here! The menu was massive and it seemed like you can order almost all kinds of noodle-joy. I tried the Sapporo Miso, and my other half tried the wasabi tonkotsu. They were both pretty good...so I'll have to come back and try some other flavours to see if I can bump this place up to 5 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

nvNLI4Nn_VmnV90kqJfPHw.text: This is the place to have a authentic Japanese ramen! The menu variety is not that big. Service is quite fast. Bathroom was dirty - I would expect a cleaner environment for these prices. Thank you for delicious ramen!

iRTjz7Ylx2zAOxVfpCrSCw.text: I would eat here every day!Excellent service, excellent food.Set menu or a la cart. Really nice place, crowded location, but good service and a manager who cares enough to stop and talk with you and ensure all is well.Good prices and fast. Atmosphere is acceptable, although nothing special.Go for the food (i.e., Ramen, buns, etc.), it's really tasty.

PE-aRz-ANZ8osbyndS6Sxg.text: I don't eat pork and presume their tonkatsu is their signature ramen, but their wafu chicken ramen isn't great.  The stock is ok, albeit a bit unappetizing in hue, and the chicken karaage is passable at best.  Kaarage is meant to be marinated, typically chicken thigh and coated in a thin dusting of potato starch or flour; theirs is chicken breast and in a tempura type batter which does not suit being submerged in soup whatsoever.  Overall a dish not worth spending money on - if they're going to offer a chicken ramen they should at least make a chicken bone broth like Bone Daddies; regurgitating the vegetarian soup and adding chicken seems like a cop-out.

PF58V259iWFiXwI6Igqr5A.text: Other Yelpers are right, the egg is pretty amazing. Rare but not too rare, just perfect. I liked the broth, and even though it's kind of odd to have bean sprouts as a topping, it was a nice addition for me (haven't been eating my veggies since I came to London... or wait since I moved out of my parent's house). The noodle is a bit hard, but still pretty good. Green tea was served with a cute little tea pot, nice containers can always make things taste better ;).Didn't like the mini salad too much. It's a bit too salty, I wish I got gyoza as a side instead. What I love the most about this place is that it's not awkward to eat alone at all. I sat  on a communal table and there were 5 or 6 people eating by themselves (most are Japanese). It makes my aloneness doesn't seem as sad.  The staff were friendly and efficient, even though none of them are Japanese they tried to greet everyone with Japanese. Besides food and service, the location is great (super close to Piccadily circus) , and the decor is minimal/clean, just the way I like it.  For someone who isn't a ramen geek, I totally enjoyed the experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Good egg

yvUeukjTHsAYouS_uKAOBA.text: Wow, I love their ramen!  "Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen" was super delicious and authentic!!  I chose "katame (hard)" for noodles, and it was just right.  Karashi Takana (mustard greens) as an extra topping was also very good but potion was huge! I would NOT RECOMMEND "gyoza".  It was totally not gyoza.I went there around 4 pm on a Wednesday. They don't close after lunch hours, which was very helpful for a tourist like me who eat lunch when it's convenient for sightseeing.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

sOUN1BcGzXrdr9YCPCeTjA.text: Love how they offer gluten free ramen! But overall, their signature ramen I ordered definately does not beat popular ones back home in SoCal. The broth was very bland, pork tasted a few days old, the boiled eggs were delish! We also ordered the chicken steamed buns and that is a must! Chicken was crispy, sauce was sweet, bun was very soft, veggies stuffed inside were fresh and crisp. So tasty!Waitresses were very attentive and sweet.

5SQBHKuzFNEPxUOYlJfnpw.text: Fantastic food in a great space. The place is a great value - easily 5 stars. I had the pork ramen and a prawn steam bun. Both were perfectly prepared and presented beautifully. The price was fantastic as well - my fiancé and I were out for less than £30 for the 2 of us - including service.

0FMIRbDxL0h7bbSTPleQdw.text: Went recently for a very quick lunch. I loved the starters which were served promptly but I came here for the main event of ramen. It was cold and I needed arming up.Compared to say Bone Daddies or Kanada-Ya all not far from here, I was quite disappointed. Did I come on an off day? I got the original Ramen Tonkotsu, which I didn't think had any depth of flavour. Pork belly also far too fatty for my liking.I'm willing to come back one day but it did put me off considering I could easily compare it to it's rivals in Soho.

cTVJq51mL1PRwv-t7ae_Hw.text: Went there at 10pm for a quick feed up. Taste almost the same as the ramen I had in US. Nothing special except being a bit too oily for me though but still not bad.

gG9U0iZD6MncvLTmVPl1mw.text: Japanese remen ( noodle ) great located , staffs really warm welcome! And noolde is so great! But sushi is soso ( dragon roll ) But overall its really great restaurant

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Cold remen...quite differ from original japan but great fusion
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Spicy remen

Vp7QatgvFbbfTaB5E5B2xw.text: This is the best ramen I've had in London and the best I've had in NYC as well. Its potentially true that the bao is not 100% perfect. I want to say maybe 98%? Some times there is a tiny bit more bun than filling and they can put a .5 gram of too much mayo on it - that's all I'll concede.Add to that its reasonably priced and the service is fantastic and I will come back here again and again. The only downside is that the quality is quite good so one can then eat a lot - one time I both ate a lot and took down some beer. Its hard to go back to work after that - you kind of want to go have an afternoon nap.Really cannot over recommend this place.

Fw95kwyieHh-ENO43H9mpg.text: Why is everything in london so expensive... Came to london for a vacation, mid week through our trip of course I start to crave asian food and whats better than a hot bowl of ramen?Shoryu specializes in tonkotsu soup base which is my favorite.  They have different option for the thickness of the broth.  If you are used to eating ramen def go with the rich broth option as their regular broth was a little on the bland side.  I love the egg as its the perfect yolk consistency.  Service was pretty good also, very fast and attentive.  While the noodles are pretty good here, it is hard to stomach the fact that I spent almost $100 US dollars here for 2 bowls of ramen, 6pc gyoza and an icecream dessert.  It cost like $30 for a bowl of ramen and $5 to add just an egg...if you are a local then definitely check out this place as their ramen is pretty good but if you are travelling from NY i would say to skip it and save the $.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

yBLqcPVoqxyzWfC_HZxMxg.text: Best ramen I have had in London. I can't wait for them to expand in NYC and Or LA. My waitress Noelle was exceptionally amazing are her service. I wish for her to serve me my next visit. I had the Fish cakes that were to Die for, the Kotteri ramen and the TAN TAN Ramen are highly recommended. Thank You

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

v3g8-3toDP5o6nOwqZu8Tg.text: Just as good as the other Shoryu chains. Key advantage of this one is that it's less busy and hectic than the other locations that are in higher footfall areas.Food is extremely consistent and I have difficulty spotting any differences between this place and the Soho branches.Most of the tables here are for 2 people so if you're an odd group you'll probably be seated on a group table, by the single seaters at the window or I guess they can merge some tables together.Check out my other reviews if you want to know what the food is like.Shoryu Carnaby - yelp.co.uk/biz/shoryu-ca…Shoryu Soho - yelp.co.uk/biz/shoryu-lo…

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Hirata Bun - Salmon

eWZdS28R6lfgwO-rvHkl4Q.text: I rarely give five stars for ramen because I enjoy a particular style and that is tonkotsu broth and not many places do it well.I walked into Shoryu for lunch solo on a weekday afternoon and didn't have to wait for a seat. The place was pretty packed for lunch.I got a Dracula ramen which is tonkotsu with garlic. Garlic oil, garlic chips, fresh minced garlic, which as one can imagine, gets a pretty strong flavor. Let's just say I wasn't kissing anyone for the whole day or even opening my mouth because I could've killed someone with my breath. Was it worth it? You bet.The broth was rich and flavorful and the flavors melded together for a heavenly experience. The ramen came with half an egg perfectly done and three slices of fatty chashu. What I REALLY enjoyed was that there was some ginger in the broth, which really contrasted well with the garlic. Anyone can throw garlic inside tonkotsu but not everyone can layer flavors like a Korean girl layers clothes. My only grouse is that there was half an egg. Just give me the whole damned egg already. Thank you.I haven't written my Bone Daddies review yet but tldr;I would choose Shoryu over Bone Daddies. I have noticed a distinct difference in the crowds at both places. Shoryu has a more Asian crowd and Bone Daddies seems to have a hipster crowd. Different strokes for different folks.

eFXRMOLi8EIHvowIHFGOug.text: I am a big fan of ramen and am always up for discovering the best shop around town. There are two Shoryu around Piccadilly Circus, which is a highly touristy area, so I am already a bit suspicious. Though a gong is rung every time a customer comes in or goes out of the shop, it doesn't make the place more Japanese. Maybe most of the servers are not Japanese or the restaurant just doesn't have the coziness which is typical of Japanese ramen places. I went there for lunch, so I just ordered Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu which is their signature ramen. Anybody who is into ramen knows that the broth is what makes or breaks ramen. Their broth is ok flavor-wise, but nothing really jumped out at me. The toppings include pickled ginger, fried shallots and black wood ear in addition to the usual roasted pork and egg. Overall, it was a good bowl of ramen but that's it. Shoryu offers a lot of side dishes ranging from sashimi, pork buns to chicken wings, which are not food you would see served at an authentic ramen shop. Call me all fashioned, a good ramen place to me should have just a few options of ramen and limited number of side dishes. Shoryu seems to be a Japanese restaurant that caters mostly to tourists and serves all sorts of Japanese dishes, one of which happens to be  Ramen. If you are looking for great ramen place, I wouldn't recommend it, but if you want some decent Japanese food in the area, this is not a bad choice.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu ganso tonkotsu

kZYArZv3bvmUGILFo8Xmzw.text: A-OK..... that sums it up.I had the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu for 11.90gbp/18usd, 3pc gyoza for 4gbp/6usd, and a drink.My bowl was small, so small I finished it even though my mouth was on fire because it was SPICY.  I'm not complaining about its spiciness, but its size...gyoza. ehh.US$33.75 for eating alone and leaving a little hungry... no thanks

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. 3 piece gyoza for 4gbp/6usd
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Karaka tan tan tonkotsu  for 11.90gbp/18usd. Small.

McCdTX3IoM9d_tNkaR2EqA.text: I've been to many ramen places in southern California, which is crawling with Asian food places including ramen. While studying abroad I was really missing a dose of Asian food and had heard such good things and was so impressed with Shoryu! I think it's the best ramen I've had yet. Now that I'm back in the States, I find myself craving Shoryu all the time. I've had the original once in Carnaby, the signature ramen twice and the Dracula once on Regent St. All were so good! The broth is amazing and the egg. Ugh, the egg. Perfect. Just how it should be done! Having gone a few times, I found it not filling enough, so I recommend rationing your broth so you can get extra noodles if you're still hungry!The plum wine is also great. A really nice complement to the savoury noodles. I didn't liked Asian steamed buns growing up but the pork belly hirata buns changed my mind. So good!Next time I'm in London, definitely making a stop at one of my favorite trendy restaurants!!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

u4GLKTBdpCYmhpR98A9L5g.text: Amazing ramen noodles I ever have, tried Piri Piri tonkotsu was delicious and their buns are just so good. Definitely would come back and recommend it to everyone

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Awesome foods

TIkO7rAOUqocLw457WxMKg.text: Having my fair share of tasty ramen from California, this place is solid. Broth is very authentic and flavorful, noodles are perfect. If you are in the area and in the mood for some ramen, this is the place to go. Keep up and improve further and some day you'll earn that Michelin Star.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

AYqErmcp8MT9F35Jae3nbw.text: What can I say, it's good ramen. Is it the best though? I personally think I've had better...Shoryru seems to be popping up everywhere and I've had the chance to try both their sit down and takeaway.It, just like all the others, is first come first served and you need to get there on time if you want to get a place to eat.As I do, I ordered the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu ramen, and make no mistake, these noodles are good, the broth flavourful and fatty as it should be. You won't be disappointed going here that's for sure.For me though, the price is a little high and the noodles just missing a little something something to make it my favourite. I'm a big advocate for making the effort to getting something good and going the distance. In this case, I think I'm going to walk a little further and get something just a bit better...

427wq_5yRrdDV-1WaSeRsQ.text: Delicious ramen!!! And, the Chef (Aris), as well as all the staff, were really nice and friendly.Ordered a bottle of sake to share for two, and did not expect such a large bottle! Definitely worthwhile :)

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. :9

wW-T4ovnVetmkAwrjCNjYA.text: All in all the experience was alright. Had heard good things about this chain, so had high expectations for an authentic banging ramen. Was pleasant, though they forgot about our sides.... Also didn't see one Japanese staff.... Was a little odd but I guess they pulled it off ok. In summary, it was ok. The space was pleasant, the service was ok... Erm... Prob a little like an upper end fast food joint though? I dunno.. Maybe I'm too picky? I'll still rate it a 3.5 out of 5.

1jLr_92SIgzEHBsltslB6w.text: Really fast service and delicious sashimi. My family enjoyed their ramen as well! It was a cool atmosphere with different kinds of seasonings available at your table for customization.

vObbONTc2Mn0MpsZSHZthg.text: Delicious, delicious ramen and buns. I got the Ganso Tonkotsu, their signature dish and Shoryu and Chicken Karage Buns. Shoryu buns because it had a lot of great reviews and Chicken Karage because they were having a BOGO special and that was what my waiter recommended. For a Michelin recommended restaurant, they surprising didn't have great presentation or at least presentation that matches their website. The ramen itself is constructed with quality ingredients. I think they use mayo as part of the sauce base which I half enjoyed, because mayo + special sauce is usually going to be pretty good, but also didn't care for since it's mayo...

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

nvYxgE0akEZ0S1TRzfMj1g.text: Horrible wait and low table turn despite the supposed fast appeal. Indecipherable menu. Slow labor all around.

6a_6vV9Y5NK7yqta9HgKrA.text: Stopped at Shoryu Ramen for a late after show snack. It was a great choice. Had their signature dish Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu which is ramen noodles served in a thick rich pork broth and garnished with deep fried shallot, pickled ginger, soft boiled egg, julienned mushroom, and seaweed paper.  We also tried gyoza, salmon sashimi, and tempura tiger prawns. The service was friendly and prompt and the atmosphere is very comfortable. Our server suggested two cold sake options that were excellent and provided a new experience for myself. The first was Tarusake which had a black pepper finish but still subtle and flavorful.  The second selection was Nigori cloudy sake which was creamy with real texture.

2TOo6rRZNnviUanaJSfbRw.text: I came back in two years and it hasn't changed much. Food was good. Prawn tempura was perfectly cooked and ramen had good flavors. I would give it a solid 4 stars but the service. There were too many of them but not well coordinated. They seemed to trip over each other.

WAXivADtIXGBhRKGzcJs1g.text: Shoryu Ramen honestly exceeded my expectations. Whoever said that food at London sucks should go check this place out.I ordered the pira pira ramen and my friend ordered the kimchi seafood ramen. The broth for both ramen tasted similiar: both spicy, thick and DELICIOUS. The egg was perfectly cooked and the pork was soft and tender. I've tried many japanese ramen places in southern california, shanghai, and seoul, and this place was hands down one of the best.The price was pretty expensive for a bowl of ramen, around 12 pounds. However, in my opinion, the ramen was worth the price and i would definitely come back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom. Pira Pira ramen

fKDg5hQruyV2uvrcHCWt3g.text: I am writing the review for the first time for those who consider to visit here... The guy who served us very unkind... i would never come here again...we asked some questions and he seemed to be annoyed by our questions and gave scornful look..

dqfatrLfyjxkTp5IMJdzPQ.text: My go-to ramen place. Great service, great food, all in fantastic locations, what's not to love.

9m6BxGbbeJP5yGcUKyOw7A.text: Great atmosphere and menu, and fantastic service. A positive, cool vibe.  Food was excellent. The Curry Ramen was delicious accompanied with a side of kimchi. Perfect lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu Ramen - London, United Kingdom

_XLVm8OSQnWunbXg4r0swA.text: Oh ramen, truly some of the ultimate comfort food. I feel as though I was a little too spoiled with my first ramen restaurant experience because I went to one of the top spots in Los Angeles and it was truly incredible. I haven't been able to get the same quality of ramen since but that isn't to say I've been dissatisfied. For a chain, Shoryu is quite good and I went twice during my week in London because I love ramen that much. The ramen is definitely better than some that Ive had before which is a good thing. I tried multiple types and they all had unique tastes to them that made them worthwhile. Some appetizers were tried as well and they had varying degrees of success. The pork belly buns are good but certainly there are better. The brussel spout tempura...uhhhhh not good. Like wow those were pretty bad.The restaurant is also quite small, surprise surprise for a London restaurant and the tables are scrunched together like you can't believe. Surely that made things a little uncomfortable but not until a group of stereotypical 16 year old asian girls with jansport backpacks as if they came straight from a Japanese anime sat right next to us. But until I can afford to rent out every restaurant I go to for the night I will have to cope with my middle class problems.

SGbM1L_mZHgGaW2TxwrfkQ.text: I thought we had happened upon this place by happenstance but it turns out it was part of my wife's masterful plan (she had researched Shoryu Ramen before we got to London). The ramen we both had was some of the richest, most flavorful and aromatic ramen broth we'd ever had. What really got me was the texture of the noodles. They were firm and had a hearty and pleasant chewiness to them. They held up to the powerful broth and abundance of stellar ingredients. It all paired wonderfully with a cold Sapporo.

dYa-7jNRv5gm0UPkI2dWEQ.text: Don't let Eve serve you!! She was rude: not only did she take the order of the couple next to me AFTER she had just seated me first, when I asked her why I had to wait, her response was that I hadn't waved my hand in the air to get her attention. Apparently everyone else in the restaurant could sit respectively, but I was expected to look like an idiot and wave my arms around. Right... Who says that to a customer?!?! She put up a little argument about taking off the service fee also. As if arguing with a customer is common practice. RUDE AND UNPROFESSIONAL.

GO6stkol2EDdACNgQQvOPQ.text: Really liked this place. This was the first ramen place to I have been in London and it didn't disappoint! I was here with a girlfriend on a Friday evening and while they don't take reservations - we came here around 7:30pm and waited for under 5 mins. The ambience is casual and the service was a bit slow, but the food was delicious. To start we ordered the edamame which was salted and lightly dusted with pepper. And for main course, I ordered the "white natural" with gluten free noodles which is served in a soy milk/mushroom  soup with mushrooms and fried tofu among other things. My ramen was quite delicious especially given that it was vegan and gluten free (a rare find!). My friend ordered the original tonkotsu which is a simple dish with pork belly, mushrooms and spring onions in a pork broth. Of course you can always add extra toppings if your heart desires. Both of us enjoyed our food and I will definitely return to try their buns which they can substitute with gluten free buns!PS: The ramen portion sizes are quite adequate. While this time, I didn't try the desserts - they do offer some cool green tea flavoured desserts.

KO29iFn4g7n8FzBD6pCRpw.text: Disappointing, both relative to other ramen restaurants in London and as an experience in and of itself. I found my main dish average (though for full disclosure, I ate the Tori Kara-Age Men which is not made with their famous pork broth) and the surrounding dishes (with the exception of a delicious Chicken Bun) unexciting. The sashimi sampler tasted as if had been sitting out for a while. And the fruit flies that were buzzing around during our meal also didn't help the ambiance... Needless to say, I was expecting more from my meal at Shoryu. And good service from a pleasant and attentive waitstaff could not make up for mediocre food.

VQNWZ-C7luOTa3aX-2FwZA.text: I was strolling through Piccadilly Circus area on Sunday on my first day in town on business.  It was about 1230 or so and I got seated quickly.  After looking at several choices, I picked the Tan Tan.  A fantastic silky tonkatsu broth, with nori, egg, scallions, pickled ginger and loads of chili oil :).As I was finishing I saw a crowd by the window.  I hadn't realized it but the placed filled up to capacity right after me and there were 15 or so people waiting in line!  It was a very good bowl of ramen and worth the visit!

_G9EkC7FFR1pJxZWHOSmPA.text: Let me start by saying I am Japanese, spent the first 18 years of my life there, and have spent the last 25 in New York City, where there is plenty of and an increasing amount of ramen competition, that most ramen connoisseurs would be proud of.  I adore ramen, and am comfortable claiming myself as a connoisseur.I am not trying to be racist, but there is a non-Japanese manager at Shoryu, who does not understand how ramen is properly consumed.  I ordered the most simple combination of a bowl of ramen and an order of gyoza.  As any seasoned ramen eater knows, each of those dishes are good on their own, but eating them together is what makes the experience whole.  Well  I received my gyoza within 5 minutes of ordering (great), but did not receive my ramen for another half hour (not great).  Given the standard ritual, I of course held off on eating my gyoza until the ramen came, and by then, it was cold, greasy, and to be honest, slimy.Now the ramen.  The soup (I had the piri piri tonkotsu) was not bad.  The noodles felt and tasted a bit like soba noodles, i.e. too straight, and too hard.  And worst of all, they make the same mistake that so many foreign ramen outposts do - they pile on the vegetables and other stuff, taking away from the taste of the ramen itself, perhaps to fool you into thinking you're getting a good bang for your buck.  True ramen, as most know, shouldn't be adulterated by too much "gu" , so you can let your tastebuds focus on and appreciate the simple noodle and soup combination.When I complained to said manager about the half hour gap between the gyoza and ramen, she simply said sorry, and quickly stuck another customer in front of me - they make you share tables, so as not to slow down business.  So those of you who feel weird about eating at a small table for two with a perfect stranger sitting eighteen inches in front of you, maybe you should venture elsewhere.  Very different from sitting next to someone at a counter, even though you are just as close.With very mediocre ramen and horrible service, I will continue to wait for the awesome ramen shop this city so desperately needs.

JC2VYaBtniTYYJGqsFyUpg.text: My girlfriend and I had a very bad experience here recently.  The Prosecco we were served was completely flat, we had to send it back.  The soft shell crab tempura was bland and the ramen although made with good stock was not worth the £11.  For the money I'd recommend a good old Wagamamas or a trip to Busaba which are a short walk from here.

X6noEhxRFFlf7jxRAUat0Q.text: Came here for dinner and we ordered their special pork bun with spicy sauce, spicy miso ramen, and Dracula ramen.  First off, the special pork bun with spicy sauce was a let down.  The pork was dry and the pork skin wasn't fried enough.  The skin kept sticking to my teeth.  The spicy sauce was mixed with mayo so it definitely cut back on its spiciness and muted it's flavors.  Perhaps another type of meat within the bun would have been better but I would not recommend the pork bun.  Now onto the ramen.  The spicy miso ramen was just okay.  First and foremost, I did not get as many ingredients as my wife.  I only got 2 pieces of meat whereas she got like 5.  In addition, the soup base was just spicy, it masked the miso flavor.  You can taste the miso flavor but the spiciness was overwhelming.  I recommend them to cut back on the spiciness and add something else to elevate the soup base profile.  The ramen for both were good, just that the soup base for Dracula was better.  It had tons of flavors, including the red ginger and garlic.  It had more depth of flavors in this soup base.  If I had tried the Dracula ramen first, this place would have gotten 4 stars.  Their service was good and friendly but they do need to pay attention to water level.  They need to re-fill the water in a more timely fashion.  I would recommend this place despite my rating because the Dracula ramen is good but don't get the buns.

6q2nhWyaqYPDFBBUUC8dQA.text: My friend and I weren't planning on having ramen in London since we'd been warned it wouldn't live up to our expectations, but Shoryu was surprisingly OK. It was a chilly spring day when we were rushing down Regent Street and we were pleased to find a place with hot broth and noodles. The noodles had an OK mouthfeel (a bit thick and squishy for my taste, which is barely al dente), and the broth we found more salty and oily than we liked. My friend got the ramen with the black sesame oil, and she didn't love it. But overall, knowing what's available ramenya-wise in London, this really wasn't that bad. It was never going to be Japan or even New York-caliber, but it was better than the average bowl.

gWdM5TLi2zE_uTrUh6abWQ.text: Just what I need in cold and rainy London.  Had the Karaka Tantan Tonkotsu and Chicken Hirata bun.  The food here competes with Ippudo in NY!

EzeT6sIvLkVC4lFfw2sknw.text: Finally... crossed the finish line of finding a delicious tonkotsu ramen in London. Amazingly savory tonkotsu broth served nice and hot with plentiful toppings (menma, bean sprouts, ginger, pork, etc.) and spot-on noodles. They add a bit of dashi to the tonkotsu broth to add a bit more flavor which def stood out (esp in comparison to Bone Daddies.) The ramen stayed warm not just from the broth being hot but also since they keep the bowls "pre-warmed up." The yuzu ramen was pretty unique and delish and so was the piri-piri tonkotsu. Can't wait to go back!

A-Tf-shIYVb1VLqLqp4tYw.text: I had the Kimchi flavored Seafood Ramen.  The broth was very good and very spicy.  The noodles were nice and al dente.  The only thing strange was the seafood (shrimp. scallops and squid) were cool (if not cold).  They were sitting on top of the broth, and seemed like they were cooked but came right out of the refrigerator.  I pushed them down into the broth and that warmed them up.  Sticking with 4 stars because the flavor was very good and they had a good, very reasonably priced Sake that I enjoyed.

uJQtigqVYIOpl4gVl9rnkg.text: How is the ramen? Who knows. After getting my pork buns and frozen beer fairly quickly, both of which were good, I waited another 30mins before the waitress realized she had never placed my ramen order. With no time left , their only solution was a paltry 10% discount for me not getting lunch.  With many other good ramen options in the area, don't bother with this one.

ABi2bcOXDF_M9fZOIft3Vg.text: So far, the best ramen I've had in London! To be honest, I found it comparable to those ramen I used to have back in Tokyo years ago. I had ramen for all the 4 times I came here, so I can't make any comments on other dishes. But anyway, the ramen is splendid! Fit, you may have to expect to wait for at least 20 minutes before geting seated sometimes, but I'm pretty sure you'll find it worth the queue!

Y9KAouM_SnDDOQ2N29PEyw.text: good egg. really effing good egg. and gyoza. I had the Sapporo miso, although I probably should've ordered something with tonkosu broth. The japanese guy next to me had the Shoryu ramen and he had added a side of rice and an extra order of noodles (+ diet coke) to finish off his soup. Daan-yam he can eat.But yes, overall a very good lunch!p.s. Think I prefer Shoryu over bone daddies... will try both again and make a decision!

69B5sRSOJOnydcVCELwPmw.text: The ramen here was excellent, and so was the kuraage. My only complaints were that the food was relatively pricey for ramen and that we were packed like sardines. Felt like a money grab. Having said that, the service was still quite reasonable.

UkzrAhajrMxHeYdXbFRiGQ.text: My friend and I were homesick for our favorite ramen place in Shinjuku, so we went on stop one of our Ramen Quest.As other Yelpers mention: the egg is awwwweeeesome. I had three. And I would have eaten another one...if I had any more space in my stomach at the end of the meal.My friend and I started out by splitting the kara age (fried chicken) and the gyoza. The kara age was excellent, just a little bit of lemon on top. But, I'm bias. I love almost any fried chicken. The gyoza was good, but I've had better. In Japan. If you know of an amazing gyoza place in London, tell me stat. Or maybe not, I haven't joined the gym yet.The ramen was delicious, great broth and noodles(and egg!!!!!). My friend and I both ordered the Shoryu ramen. I do wish they had the multitude of toppings out on the table like Bone Daddies or in Japan so you can tweak your ramen to your liking. They did have that chili oil however, which is what I really love. At the end of the meal we were stuffed!! I think I waddled out of the restaurant. So far, it's my favorite ramen in London, but, I think I might have to do a few more tests...hmmmm ;)

xC0Cfmy74pRTPRsbNTQ45w.text: This place is delicious! Rice balls, sushi and some very filling ramen make for a great meal.  It was super crowded though thankfully my brother had arrived much earlier to get us a table.  The ramen noodles and broth are great. This is one of my preferred ramen places, and was definitely one of the better meals I ate on my trip.  I will be sure to suggest Shoryu to friends.

Qrp9A7kA4y197GV7OJDIuQ.text: After a trip to Japan, I've been searching for real ramen! Living in Cleveland, OH... the choices were few and far between. Imagine my happiness when I walked by Shoryu on a recent trip to London! The broth was a milky brown, the eggs were perfectly boiled, everything was spot on. I didn't think it was overly expensive (about 15 pounds per bowl) and I loved that they had stronger flavor options for your broth. I've had a lot of ramen disappointments and this was not one of them!

BkYhWVm5F2YQkc2GR2i8Lg.text: I went along to this extended soft opening to take advantage of the half price extravaganza on ramen goodness (which I wouldn't have known about unless Desi F. was around). There was of course some buzz and a line was naturally out the door, the only place really as it was a small restaurant. Still, the wait was only 15 minutes and then we were there, close enough we could be served the soup and noodle goodness we had been smelling for 15 minutes. The majority of the staff, apart from 1, were very polite and attentive. Also the old guy running the place was Japanese as was many of the patrons so I felt confident in the quality. And that quality didn't disappoint. It was a very generous bowl of ramen noodles with some veg and pork in a cloudy broth. The pork was a tasty BBQ pork and there could have been a little more. However, the main attraction, the ramen noodles, were very nice and on the whole it was a filling and tasty dish. The restaurant isn't small enough to feel intimate but they were fast and played light jazz music and the dichotomy worked really well. I think at full price it's a push (£8 usually) to be good value for money but definitely worth a few visits. Just save the visits till after payday.

TcFLNDXMt67yppwG7JoXXA.text: I thought it was delicious; had the standard ramen soup with the spicy mustard greens. Perhaps a bit expensive but not for London. Service was great (and is added on the bill). I waited a good fifteen for a seat -- very popular for weekend lunch. I don't think ramen is health food, exactly; pretty rich stuff.

iLIB1t407ZDquh0jijIdmA.text: I have been to the place twice and I have to say its really disappointing. Their ramen is bland and nothing special. The broth and noodles are a-ok. The pork is fine, nothing special. You only get half an egg and it is flavourless and borderline hard-boiled. I was really excited when this place opened, but I think my ramen loyalties for London are firmly sitting with Bone Daddies
